revision.text:
[[File:Ten Cents a Dance FilmPoster.jpeg|thumb|200px|right|Poster for the film ''[[Ten Cents a Dance (1931 film)|Ten Cents a Dance]]'' (1931) with [[Barbara Stanwyck]] as a taxi dancer.]] A '''taxi dancer''' is a paid dance partner in a [[partner dance]]. Taxi dancers are hired to dance with their customers on a dance-by-dance basis. When taxi dancing first appeared in [[Taxi dance hall|taxi-dance halls]] during the early 20th century in the United States, male patrons would typically buy dance tickets for a small sum each.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 3, 11, 17.</ref><ref name=BurgessCressey>{{cite book|first=Ernest |last=Burgess| chapter=Introduction | pages=xxviii |title=The Taxi-Dance Hall:A Sociological Study in Commercialized Recreation and City Life |location= Montclair,NJ | publisher= Paterson Smith Publishing |year=1969|isbn=0875850766}}</ref><ref>Freeland (2009), p. 192.</ref> When a patron presented a ticket to a chosen taxi dancer, she would dance with him for the length of a single song. The taxi dancers would earn a [[Commission (remuneration)|commission]] on every dance ticket earned. Though taxi dancing has for the most part disappeared in the United States, it is still practiced in some other countries.
==Etymology== The term "taxi dancer" comes from the fact that, as with a [[taxicab|taxi-cab]] driver, the dancer's pay is proportional to the time he or she spends dancing with the customer. Patrons in a [[Taxi dance hall|taxi-dance hall]] typically purchased dance tickets for ten cents each, which gave rise to the term "dime-a-dance girl". Other names for a taxi dancer are "dance hostess", "taxi" (in Argentina), and "nickel hopper" because out of that dime they typically earned five cents.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}}
==History== {{Main|Taxi dance hall}}
[[File:Taxi Dancer lobby card.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Lobby card for ''[[The Taxi Dancer]]'' (1927)]]
Taxi dancing traces its origins to the [[Barbary Coast, San Francisco|Barbary Coast]] district of [[San Francisco]] which evolved from the [[California Gold Rush|California Gold Rush of 1849]]. In its heyday the Barbary Coast was an economically thriving place of mostly men that was frequented by gold prospectors and sailors from all over the world.<ref>Asbury (1933), p. 3.</ref> That district created a unique form of dance hall called the ''Barbary Coast dance hall'', also known as the ''Forty-Nine['49] dance hall''. Within a Barbary Coast dance hall female employees danced with male patrons, and earned their living from commissions paid for by the drinks they could encourage their male dance partners to buy.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 179.</ref>
Still later after the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake|San Francisco Earthquake of 1906]] and during early days of [[jazz]] music, a new entertainment district developed in San Francisco and was nicknamed [[Terrific Street]].<ref>Knowles (1954), p. 64.</ref><ref>Asbury (1933), p. 99.</ref><ref>Stoddard (1982), p. 10.</ref> And within that district an innovative dance hall, ''The So Different Club'', implemented a system where customers could buy a token which entitled them to one dance with a female employee.<ref>Stoddard (1982), p. 13.</ref><ref name=Richards1>{{cite book| first=Rand| last=Richards | title=Historic Walks in San Francisco| pages= 183 | location= San Francisco | publisher=Heritage House Publishers| year=2002 | isbn= 1879367033 }}</ref> Since dancing had become a popular pastime, many of The So Different Club's patrons would go there to see and learn the latest new dances.<ref>Asbury (1933), p. 293.</ref>
However in 1913 San Francisco enacted new laws that would forbid dancing in any cafe or saloon where alcohol was served.<ref>Asbury (1933), p. 303.</ref> The closure of the dance halls on Terrific Street fostered a new kind of pay-to-dance scheme, called a ''closed dance hall'', which did not serve alcohol.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 181.</ref> That name was derived from the fact that female customers were not allowed — the only women permitted in these halls were the dancing female employees.<ref>Report of Public Dance Hall Committee of San Francisco of California Civic League of Women Voters, p.14</ref> The closed dance hall introduced the ''ticket-a-dance'' system which became the centerpiece of the taxi-dance hall business model.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 181.</ref> A taxi dancer would earn her income by the number of tickets she could collect in exchange for dances.
Taxi dancing then spread to [[Chicago]] where dance academies, which were struggling to survive, began to adopt the ticket-a-dance system for their students.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 183.</ref> The first instance of the ticket-a-dance system in Chicago occurred at Mader-Johnson Dance Studios. The dance studio's owner, Godfrey Johnson, describes his innovation: {{blockquote|I was in New York during the summer of 1919, and while there visited a new studio opened by Mr. W___ W___ of San Francisco, where he had introduced a ten-cent-ticket-a-dance plan. When I got home I kept thinking of that plan as a way to get my advanced students to come back more often and to have experience dancing with different instructors. So I decided to put a ten-cent-a-lesson system in the big hall on the third floor of my building... But I soon noticed that it wasn't my former pupils who were coming up to dance, but a rough hoodlum element from Clark Street... Things went from bad to worse; I did the best I could to keep the hoodlums in check.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 184.</ref>}}
This system was so popular at dance academies, that taxi dancing quickly spread to an increasing number of non-instructional taxi-dance halls.
Taxi dancers typically received half of the ticket price as salary and the other half paid for the orchestra, dance hall, and operating expenses.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 3.</ref> Although they only worked a few hours a night, they frequently made two to three times the salary of a woman working in a factory or a store.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 12.</ref> At that time, the taxi-dance hall surpassed the public ballroom in becoming the most popular place for urban dancing.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. xxxiii.</ref>
Taxi-dance halls flourished in the United States during the 1920s and 1930s, as scores of taxi-dance halls opened in Chicago, New York, and other major cities. In 1931 there were over 100 taxi-dance halls in New York City, and between 35,000 and 50,000 men would go to these halls every week.<ref>Ronald VanderKooi, University of Illinois at Chicago Circle, March 1969.</ref><ref>Freeland (2009), p. 190.</ref>
However by the mid 1920s, the taxi-dance halls were coming under attack by reform movements that insisted on licensing and police supervision, and they succeeded in closing down some taxi-dance halls for lewd behavior.<ref>Freeland (2009), p. 194.</ref> And in San Francisco where it all started, the police commission ruled against the employment of women as taxi dancers in 1921, and taxi dancing in San Francisco would forever become illegal.<ref>Cressey (1932), p. 182.</ref> After [[World War II]] the popularity of taxi dancing in the United States began to diminish, and most of its taxi-dance halls disappeared by the 1960s.<ref>Clyde Vedder: ''Decline of the Taxi-Dance Hall'', Sociology and Social Research, 1954.</ref>
Paul G. Cressey's book, entitled ''The Taxi-Dance Hall: A Sociological Study in Commercialized Recreation and City Life'', gives a history of taxi dance halls, with interviews with taxi dancers and patrons. Various films and novels chronicled the lives of taxi dancers. For example, in 1927 [[Joan Crawford]] starred in the film ''[[The Taxi Dancer]]'', and actor [[Ed Wynn]] starred in the [[Ziegfeld]] Broadway [[Musical theatre|musical]] ''[[Simple Simon (musical)|Simple Simon]]'', which popularized the song "[[Ten Cents a Dance]]", which in turn inspired the 1931 film [[Ten Cents a Dance (1931 film)|''Ten Cents a Dance'']], starring [[Barbara Stanwyck]].
==Taxi dancers today==
Taxi dancers may dance among paying customers to raise the standard or dance among the beginners to encourage them to continue learning. In the latter situation, taxi dancers often provide their services, without pay, with the general goal of building the dance community.
In social settings and social forms of dance, a partner wanting constructive feedback from a taxi dancer must explicitly request it. As the taxi dancer's role is primarily social, she is unlikely to criticize her partner directly. Due to the increased profile of partner dances during the 2000s, taxi dancing has become more common in settings where partners are in short supply, involving male and female dancers. For example, male dancers are often employed on [[cruise ship]]s to dance with single female passengers. This is usually called [[Cruise ship dance host|Dance Host]]. Taxi dancers (male and female) are also available for hire in Vienna, Austria, where dozens of formal balls are held each year.
Volunteer taxi dancers (experienced male and female dancers) are used in [[dance]] styles such as [[Ceroc]] to help beginners.
===In the United States === Paying to dance with a female employee is available in some nightclubs of the United States, including many in [[Los Angeles]]. These clubs no longer use the ticket-a-dance system, but have [[Time clock|time-clocks]] and [[Time card|punch-cards]] that allow the patron to pay for the dancer's time by the hour. Some of these modern dance clubs operate in buildings where taxi dancing was done in the early 20th century. No longer called taxi-dance halls, these latter-day establishments are now called [[hostess club]]s.<ref name="stranger">Evan Wright, [http://www.laweekly.com/news/dance-with-a-stranger-2130263 "Dance With A Stranger"], ''LA Weekly'', January 20, 1999</ref>
For official purposes, in the United States their occupation was sometimes referred to as a 'dancer', when they worked in taxi-dance halls that had all the necessary [[business permit]]s. But there were some professional secretaries who were moonlighting and legally worked part-time as a dancer.
===In Argentina=== The growth of [[tango]] tourism in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]], has led to an increase in formal and informal taxi dancing services in the [[Milonga (place)|''milongas'']], or dance halls. While some operators are trying to sell holiday romance, reputable tango taxi agencies offer genuine services to tourists who find it hard to cope with the ''cabeceo''—eye contact and nodding—method of finding a dance partner.
==See also== *[[Taxi dance hall]] *[[Ballroom dance]] *[[Stripper]]
==References== {{Reflist}} [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/nov/18/argentina.dance Strictly tango for the dance tourists], by Uki Goni, The Observer, London, 18 November 2007
==Sources==
*{{cite book | last= Asbury | first=Herbert | authorlink=Herbert Asbury | title=The Barbary Coast: An Informal History of the San Francisco Underworld | publisher= Thunder's Mouth Press | year=1933 | isbn= 9781560254089 }} *{{cite book | last= Cressey |first=Paul| title=The Taxi-Dance Hall: A Sociological Study in Commercialized Recreation and City Life | publisher=University of Chicago Press | year=1932 | isbn=9780226120515 }} *{{cite book | last= Stoddard |first=Tom | title=Jazz On The Barbary Coast | publisher= Heyday Books | year=1982 | isbn= 189077104X }} *{{cite book | last1= Montanarelli |first1=Lisa|last2=Harrison|first2=Ann | title=Strange But True San Francisco: Tales of the City by the Bay | publisher=Globe Pequot Press |year=2005 | isbn=076273681X }} *{{cite book | last= Knowles |first=Mark|title=The Wicked Waltz and Other Scandalous Dances | publisher=McFarland & Company | year=1954 }} *{{cite book | last=Freeland |first=David | title=Automats, Taxi Dances, and Vaudeville: Excavating Manhattan's Lost Places of Leisure | publisher=NYU Press |year=2009 | isbn=0814727638 }}

revision.text:
{{Outdated as of | topic = Internet | last updated = year = 2013 }} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox company |name = Telstra Media |logo = |type = [[Product (business)|Product]] of [[Telstra]] |foundation = 1996 as '''Telstra Corporation''' |location_city = [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria, Australia|VIC]] |location_country = Australia |key_people = Andy Penn
Group Managing Director |industry = [[Telecommunications]] / [[Electronic media|Media]] |services = [[Internet service provider]]
News
[[Email]]
[[TV on demand|Online Television]] |parent = [[Telstra]] |num_employees = 10,500 (2007) |homepage = {{URL|media.telstra.com.au/home.html|media.telstra.com.au}} }} '''Telstra Media''' (formerly known as '''BigPond''') is an Australian [[Internet service provider]] and a [[product (business)|product]] of [[Telstra]]. It is Australia's largest{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=JUlX2l7vkr4C&pg=PA96&lpg=PA96&dq=Telstra+Media+(formerly+known+as+BigPond)+is+an+Australian+Internet+service+provider+and+a+product+of+Telstra.+It+is+Australia's+largest&source=bl&ots=Sn78kqrS5q&sig=zZNImT3jCTG4afGczVqw6gKzEqk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi69c_xjrbZAhUHLpQKHRB5BigQ6AEIngEwDw#v=onepage&q=Telstra%20Media%20(formerly%20known%20as%20BigPond)%20is%20an%20Australian%20Internet%20service%20provider%20and%20a%20product%20of%20Telstra.%20It%20is%20Australia's%20largest&f=false|title=42 Rules of Product Management (2nd Edition)|last=Lawley|first=Brian|date=2012|publisher=Happy About|isbn=9781607730910|language=en}}{{Citation needed|date=July 2015}} ISP and is based in [[Melbourne]]. The BigPond brand has been in the process of being phased out in favour of full Telstra branding since 2013. As of May 2016, BigPond Movies is the only remaining service using BigPond branding.{{cite web | url = http://www.itnews.com.au/news/telstra-hits-another-nail-in-bigpond-coffin-419710 | title = Telstra hits another nail in BigPond coffin | last = Coyne | first = Allie | publisher = IT News | date = 18 May 2016 | accessdate = 18 October 2016}} ==Internet== Note that the remainder of the article has not been changed to reflect the name change from BigPond to Telstra Media. Telstra Media offers five types of Internet access; *'''Cable''' – BigPond is Australia's largest provider of [[Cable Internet access]], which covers parts of Australia's main cities ([[Adelaide]], [[Brisbane]], [[Melbourne]], [[Perth]], [[Sydney]], and the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]]). Speeds available are 'Turbo' (8 Mbit/s [[downstream (networking)|downstream]], 128 kbit/s [[upstream (networking)|upstream]]), 'Elite' (30 Mbit/s down, 1 Mbit/s up) and 'Ultimate' (100 Mbit/s down, 2 Mbit/s up). *'''ADSL''' – BigPond provides both [[ADSL]] and [[ADSL2+]] services where available, with speeds ranging from 256 kbit/s down/64 kbit/s up to 20 Mbit/s down/1 Mbit/s up. The current speeds available on ADSL plans that BigPond offers are "up to" 1.5 Mbit/s down/256 kbit/s up, "up to" 8 Mbit/s down/384 kbit/s up and "up to" 20 Mbit/s down/1 Mbit/s up. :'''Naked DSL''' – A six-week trial of two kinds of naked DSL to "assess customer demand" was launched on 1 June 2010. 'Pure DSL' having the ability to receive incoming calls and make emergency calls, and 'Naked DSL' being offered without a dial tone.{{cite web|url=http://www.zdnet.com.au/telstra-bigpond-trials-naked-dsl-339303582.htm |title=Telstra BigPond trials naked DSL |publisher=Ben Grubb, ZDNet.com.au |date=2010-06-02 |accessdate=2010-06-02| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100604030756/http://www.zdnet.com.au/telstra-bigpond-trials-naked-dsl-339303582.htm| archivedate= 4 June 2010 | deadurl= no}} * '''Mobile Broadband''' – Through Telstra's [[Telstra Mobile|Next G]] network, BigPond provides the largest wireless network coverage in Australia, reaching 99% of the population.{{cite web|url=http://www.telstra.com.au/mobile/networks/coverage/broadband.html|title=Mobile Broadband Coverage|publisher=Telstra|accessdate=19 January 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100123084303/http://www.telstra.com.au/mobile/networks/coverage/broadband.html| archivedate= 23 January 2010 | deadurl= no}} Download speeds on the 3G network range from 256 kbit/s to 3.5 Mbit/s in regional and interurban areas, and "up to" 21 Mbit/s in metropolitan and city areas. Download speeds on the 4G Network are "up to" 40Mbit/s. BigPond also provides wireless '[[Hotspot (Wi-Fi)|hot spots]]'.{{cite web|url=http://www.telstra.com.au/wirelesshotspots/index.htm |title=Telstra Wireless Hotspots |publisher=Telstra.com.au |date= |accessdate=2010-01-19| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091228021456/http://www.telstra.com.au/wirelesshotspots/index.htm| archivedate= 28 December 2009 | deadurl= no}} * '''Satellite''' – Bigpond provides Satellite internet mainly for regional customers who are too far away from the exchange to get ADSL, and cannot get Cable. Satellite is delivered via 2-way Satellite with speeds ranging from 256 kbit/s down/64 kbit/s up to 800 kbit/s down/128 kbit/s up.{{cite web|url=http://my.bigpond.com/internetplans/broadband/satellite/2_way_plans/default.jsp |title=Satellite plans and pricing |publisher=My.bigpond.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228170107/http://my.bigpond.com:80/internetplans/broadband/satellite/2_way_plans/default.jsp |archivedate=28 February 2009 |df=dmy }} * '''Dialup''' – BigPond has moved customers off dialup to a broadband platform, and in 2006 its broadband customers surpassed the number of dialup customers. ==Customer service== In 2007 a survey of 14,000 people by ''[[PC Authority]]'' magazine found BigPond users rated poorly for customer service, and less than a third considered their service a value for the money. However, BigPond argued that the survey's structure had encouraged people to provide extreme opinions.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/technology/telstras-bigpond-bombs-out-with-users/story-e6frfrnr-1111115054198?from=mostpop|title=Telstra's BigPond bombs out with consumers|last=Ramadge|first=A|date=7 December 2007|publisher=News.com.au|accessdate=17 March 2010}} The Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO) reported 14,692 complaints against Telstra BigPond for the period 1 January 2009 – 31 March 2009.[http://www.tio.com.au/statisticsByMember.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521174253/http://www.tio.com.au/statisticsByMember.htm |date=21 May 2009 }} This reflected 47.5% of all complaints against all internet service providers reported to the TIO in Australia in that period. Customer Service, Complaints Handling, Faults & Provision accounted for 8,103 complaints in that period. BigPond uses offshore call centres to provide most of their technical support. The Technical Support 133933 number connects through a VoIP line to support staff based in The Philippines, by call centre outsource companies, TeleTech & Teleperformance.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/small-business/telstra-jobs-head-to-philippines-20090619-cqoj.html|title=Telstra jobs head to Philippines|last=Schneiders|first=Ben|date=10 October 2008|publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=17 March 2010}} Technical Support officers have limited ability to resolve issues and cannot refer any issue to a Complaint Handling Officer or Customer Advocate. If the support call relates to network issues the Technical Support team cannot take any action to resolve the problem.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} In November 2009 Telstra chief executive [[David Thodey]] promised a "new Telstra" which will be much more responsive to its customers in a bid to improve the telco's corporate reputation, stating that the new mantra at Telstra would be "customer service, customer service, customer service", and announcing increases in speed and data allowances for BigPond customers.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/ets-pushes-telstra-issue-to-parliamentary-backburner/story-e6frg8zx-1225804353385|title= ETS pushes Telstra issue to parliamentary backburner |last=Korporaal|first=Glenda|date=27 November 2009|work=The Australian|accessdate=17 March 2010}} ==Services== ===BigPond Music=== BigPond operated a music download store, offering 15 million tracks encoded at either 256kbit/s or 320kbit/s in MP3 format. In April 2012, [[MOG (online music)|MOG]] announced a partnership with Telstra to bring MOG to Australia, the first region outside of the US to have access.http://exchange.telstra.com.au/2012/04/17/mog-powered-by-telstra-a-massive-deal-for-music-lovers/ Telstra and MOG launched under the BigPond Music branding on 21 June 2012.{{cite web|url=http://blog.mog.com/post.php?num%3D638184929 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=6 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629013437/http://blog.mog.com/post.php?num=638184929 |archivedate=29 June 2012 }} The BigPond Music service ended in late 2014. ===BigPond Games and GameArena=== GameArena was a website dedicated to [[video gaming]] operating under the BigPond brand that was managed by Mammoth Media and based on the east coast of Australia. The site provided news, downloads and servers primarily for the [[Personal computer|PC]], and [[Macintosh|Mac]], though it later branched out to include console sites. GameArena provided an online game shop GameNow, which sported various benefits to Telstra customers.{{cite web|url=http://www.itwire.com/content/view/4702/127/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314191225/http://www.itwire.com:80/content/view/4702/127/ |archivedate=14 March 2008 |df=dmy }} ITWire article on GameNow Usage of the GameArena file library, gaming servers and booking service were freely available to anyone, but provided specific advantages to Telstra customers such as preference in downloads and unmetered usage, as well as various bonuses in competitions. In 2005, GameArena went through a new shift with the merging of GameNow and Gameshop into itself. The name became simply BigPond GameArena.http://pcworld.idg.com.au/index.php?id=976973335 PC World GameArena article GameArena once operated over 100 gaming servers, which were monitored by a volunteer force of administrators, known as GameOps. ''GameCreate'' was a service offered free of charge where users may book a server for a specific game for a 2-hour period of time. This server was private and could be used for either ladder training or social events.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamearena.com.au/getconnected/servers/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927203652/http://www.gamearena.com.au/getconnected/servers/ |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }} GameArena list of servers GameArena servers and its website closed on 20 October 2014.{{cite web | url = http://www.mcvpacific.com/news/read/telstra-confirms-it-is-closing-game-arena/0138403 | title = Telstra confirms it is closing Game Arena | date = 2014-09-16 | accessdate = 2015-06-30 | publisher = MCV Pacific}} ===The Pond in ''Second Life''=== Telstra BigPond owned and operated a number of virtual islands in the online game ''[[Second Life]]''{{cite web|url=http://my.bigpond.com/pond/secondlife |title=The Pond on Second Life |publisher=My.bigpond.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-23}} for approximately three years. BigPond closed its ''Second Life'' presence in December 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/bigpond-pulls-plug-on-second-life-20091117-ijq2.html |first=Louisa | last=Hearn |title=BigPond pulls plug on Second Life |work=Sydney Morning Herald |date=2009-11-17 |accessdate=2010-01-19| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100120164824/http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/bigpond-pulls-plug-on-second-life-20091117-ijq2.html| archivedate= 20 January 2010 | deadurl= no}} ==See also== {{Portal|Television in Australia}} *[[Internet television in Australia]] *[[Subscription television in Australia]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|media.telstra.com.au/home.html}} {{Internet service providers of Australia}} {{Australian streaming companies}} {{Video digital distribution platforms}} [[Category:Internet service providers of Australia]] [[Category:Online content distribution]] [[Category:Online music stores]] [[Category:Telstra]] [[Category:Video rental services]] [[Category:Australian streaming companies]]

[[Showtime Networks]] | distributor = | channel = [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] | picture_format = | audio_format = [[Dolby Digital]] 5.1 | first_aired = {{Start date|2014|10|12}} | last_aired = present | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.sho.com/the-affair | website_title = Official website | production_website = }} '''''The Affair''''' is an American [[television drama series]] created by [[Sarah Treem]] and [[Hagai Levi]].{{cite news|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title=Showtime To Pick Up Drama 'The Affair', Philip Seymour Hoffman Comedy To Series|url=http://deadline.com/2014/01/showtime-to-pick-up-drama-the-affair-philip-seymour-hoffman-comedy-to-series-665322/|accessdate=August 29, 2014|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=January 16, 2014}} The series premiered on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] on October 12, 2014. A TV-14 version of the pilot episode was made available online beginning on October 6, 2014, via YouTube, SHO.com, and several other on-demand formats.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2014/10/the-affair-premiere-showtime-sneaking-early-look-today-846592/ |title=‘The Affair’ Premiere: Showtime Sneaking Early Look Today |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=October 6, 2014 |accessdate=October 12, 2014}} A 12-episode second season of ''The Affair'' premiered on October 4, 2015.{{cite news|last1=Bibel|first1=Sara|title='Homeland' Season 5 & 'The Affair' Season 2 to Premiere Sunday, October 4 on Showtime|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/07/23/homeland-season-5-the-affair-season-2-to-premiere-sunday-october-4-on-showtime/436133/|accessdate=July 23, 2015|work=[[TV by the Numbers]]|date=July 23, 2015}} On December 9, 2015, the series was renewed for a third season,{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2015/12/09/homeland-renewed-season-6-showtime/ |title=''Homeland'', ''The Affair'' Renewed |publisher=TVLine |first=Michael |last=Ausiello |date=December 9, 2015 |accessdate=December 9, 2015}} which debuted on November 20, 2016.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/shameless-the-affair-masters-of-sex-season-premiere-dates-showtime-1201786896/ |title=‘Shameless,’ ‘The Affair,’ ‘Masters of Sex’ Season Premiere Dates Set at Showtime |work=Variety |first=Daniel |last=Holloway |date=June 1, 2016 |accessdate=June 1, 2016}} On January 9, 2017, Showtime renewed the series for a fourth season,{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2017/01/the-affair-renewed-season-4-showtime-tca-1201881666/ |title=‘The Affair’ Renewed For Season 4 By Showtime Ahead Of Season 3 Finale – TCA |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |date=January 9, 2017 |accessdate=January 9, 2017}} which premiered on June 17, 2018.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/showtime-premiere-dates-billions-the-affair-benedict-cumberbatch-patrick-melrose-our-cartoon-president-1202655524/ |title=Showtime Sets Premiere Dates for ‘Billions’ and ‘The Affair,’ Releases Trailer for Benedict Cumberbatch’s ‘Patrick Melrose’ |work=Variety |first=Joe |last=Otterson |date=January 7, 2018 |accessdate=January 7, 2018}} On July 26, 2018, Showtime announced it had renewed the series for a fifth and final season to debut in 2019. The 10-episode fifth season, featuring several cast changes, will partly take place 20-30 years after the events of season four, featuring [[Anna Paquin]] as an adult Joanie Lockhart.{{cite web |url=https://tvline.com/2018/11/09/the-affair-anna-paquin-season-5-time-jump-joanie/ |title=Anna Paquin Joins The Affair's Final Season as [Spoiler] Amid Significant Time Jump — Blind Item Revealed |work=TVLine |first=Michael |last=Ausiello |date=November 9, 2018 |accessdate=November 9, 2018}} The series won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Television Series – Drama]] and [[Ruth Wilson]] won for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Television Series Drama|Best Actress – Television Series Drama]] at the [[72nd Golden Globe Awards]] in 2015. At the [[73rd Golden Globe Awards]] in 2016, [[Maura Tierney]] won the award for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Series, Miniseries or Television Film|Best Supporting Actress]]. ==Series overview== ''The Affair'' explores the emotional effects of an extramarital relationship between Noah Solloway and Alison Lockhart ([[Dominic West]] and [[Ruth Wilson]]) after they casually meet at the diner where Alison works. The show begins with the Solloway family packing up the family van to stay in the resort town of [[Montauk, New York]]. Noah is happily married with four children, but he resents their dependence on his wealthy father-in-law. Alison is a local waitress trying to piece her life and marriage back together in the wake of her young son's tragic accidental death at the age of four. The story of the affair is depicted from Noah's and Alison's perspectives respectively, complete with memory bias which often results in vastly different scenarios.{{cite press |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2014/08/26/showtime-releases-key-art-for-the-affair-premiering-sunday-october-12th-at-10-pm-et-pt-893100/20140826showtime03/ |title=Showtime(R) Releases Key Art for "The Affair," Premiering Sunday, October 12th at 10 PM ET/PT |publisher=Showtime |date=August 26, 2014 |accessdate=October 8, 2014}} Each episode has two parts, one as remembered by Noah, the other by Alison. Noah's perspective is of a vibrant, playful, and sexy Alison who comes on to him, while her perspective is more cautious, reserved, with a dulled conservative sense of self, and Noah coming on to her. In the second season, the narrative is expanded to include the perspectives of Noah and Alison's original spouses, Helen Solloway and Cole Lockhart ([[Maura Tierney]] and [[Joshua Jackson]]), as they all move forward with the dissolution of their marriages and deal with the ramifications.{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/08/11/affair-season-2-four-perspectives |title=''The Affair'' boss explains how season 2 will work with four perspectives |work=Entertainment Weekly |first=Samantha |last=Highfill |date=August 11, 2015 |accessdate=November 23, 2016}} The subsequent death of Alison's brother-in-law, Scott ([[Colin Donnell]]), and the ensuing police investigation and criminal trial, are explored in [[flashforward]] scenes at the end of most episodes. The third season is set three years later, following the culmination of the flashforward trial scenes, after Noah is released from prison. Season 3 introduces an occasional perspective, Juliette Le Gall ([[Irène Jacob]]), Noah's new love interest.{{cite web |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2016/08/the-affair-season-three-new-character |title=''The Affair'' Unveils Game-Changing Season 3 Twist |work=Vanity Fair |first=Julie |last=Miller |date=August 11, 2016 |accessdate=November 23, 2016}} In the fourth season, Noah has moved to Los Angeles to be closer to his younger children Trevor (Jadon Sand) and Stacey (Abigail Dylan Harrison), as Helen and Vik ([[Omar Metwally]]) have moved there. Cole and Luisa ([[Catalina Sandino Moreno]]) are living together in Montauk, while Alison is working as a grief counselor. Season 4 features opening [[flashforward]] sequences, featuring Noah and Cole, in its first four episodes, which ultimately lead to the discovery of Alison's death. The fifth season will take place in two different time frames: a present-day storyline including Noah, Helen, and their four children and the other decades later featuring a now-adult Joanie Lockhart ([[Anna Paquin]]) returning to Montauk to find out the truth about her mother's death. ==Episodes== {{main|List of The Affair episodes}} {{:List of The Affair episodes}} ==Cast== ===Main cast=== Characters marked "Perspective" have parts of episodes told from their point of view. {{Color box|#ddffdd|border=darkgray}} Main {{Color box|#ffe3e3|border=darkgray}} Recurring {{Color box|#DAEBFF|border=darkgray}} Guest {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:160px;" |Actor ! style="width:140px;" rowspan="2"|Character ! colspan="5"|Season |- ! style="width:50px;"|1 ! style="width:50px;"|2 ! style="width:50px;"|3 ! style="width:50px;"|4 ! style="width:50px;"|5{{cite web |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2018/11/09/academy-award-winner-anna-paquin-joins-the-showtime-drama-series-the-affair-as-a-series-regular-for-the-fifth-and-final-season-897403/20181109showtime01/ |title=Academy Award Winner Anna Paquin Joins the Showtime(R) Drama Series "The Affair" as a Series Regular for the Fifth and Final Season |publisher=Showtime |via=The Futon Critic |date=November 9, 2018 |accessdate=November 15, 2018}} |- | [[Dominic West]] || Noah Solloway || colspan="5" {{cMain|Perspective}} |- | [[Ruth Wilson]] || Alison Bailey || colspan="4" {{cMain|Perspective}} || {{cNone}} |- | [[Maura Tierney]] || Helen Butler || {{cMain|}} || colspan="4" {{cMain|Perspective}} |- | [[Joshua Jackson]] || Cole Lockhart || {{cMain|}} || colspan="3" {{cMain|Perspective}} || {{cNone}} |- | [[Julia Goldani Telles]] || Whitney Solloway || colspan="5" {{cMain|}} |- | [[Jake Siciliano]] || Martin Solloway || colspan="3" {{cMain|}} || colspan="2" {{cGuest|}} |- | Jadon Sand || Trevor Solloway || colspan="5" {{cMain|}} |- | Leya Catlett || Stacey Solloway{{efn|name=Stacey|Abigail Dylan Harrison portrays Stacey Solloway beginning with season three, but is credited as a guest star.}} || colspan="2" {{cMain|}} || colspan="3" {{cNone}} |- | [[Josh Stamberg]] || Max Cadman || {{cRecurring|}} || {{cMain|}} || {{cGuest|}} || colspan="2" {{cNone}} |- | [[Catalina Sandino Moreno]] || Luisa León || {{cNone}} || {{cRecurring|}} || colspan="2" {{cMain|}} || {{cNone}} |- | [[Omar Metwally]] || Vik Ullah || {{cNone}} || {{cRecurring|}} || {{cMain|}} || {{cMain|Perspective}} || {{cGuest|}} |- | [[Irène Jacob]] || Juliette Le Gall || colspan="2" {{cNone}} || {{cMain|Perspective}} || colspan="2" {{cNone}} |- | [[Sanaa Lathan]] || Jenelle Wilson || colspan="3" {{cNone}} || colspan="2" {{cMain|}} |- | [[Anna Paquin]] || Joanie Lockhart || colspan="4" {{cNone}} || {{cMain|}} |} {{notelist}} ===Recurring cast=== * [[Victor Williams]] as Detective Jeffries (seasons 1–2, 4) * [[John Doman]] as Bruce Butler, Helen's father (seasons 1–3, 5) * [[Kathleen Chalfant]] as Margaret Butler, Helen's mother (seasons 1–3, 5) * [[Mare Winningham]] as Cherry Lockhart, Cole's mother (seasons 1–2, 4) * [[Colin Donnell]] as Scott Lockhart, Cole's brother (seasons 1–2) * Danny Fischer as Hal Lockhart, Cole's brother (seasons 1–4) * Michael Godere as Caleb Lockhart, Cole's brother (seasons 1–4) * Kaija Matiss as Mary-Kate Lockhart, Hal's wife (seasons 1–2, 4) * [[Deirdre O'Connell (actress)|Deirdre O'Connell]] as Athena Bailey, Alison's mother (seasons 1–2, 4) * Darren Goldstein as Oscar Hodges, owner of The Lobster Roll (seasons 1–4) * [[Nicolette Robinson]] as Jane, waitress at The Lobster Roll (seasons 1–2, 4) * [[Stephen Kunken]] as Harry, a publisher (seasons 1–2) * [[Lynn Cohen]] as Joan Bailey, Alison's grandmother (season 1) * [[Jennifer Esposito]] as Nina Solloway, Noah's sister (seasons 2–3) * [[Richard Schiff]] as Jon Gottlief, Noah's attorney (season 2) * [[Joanna Gleason]] as Yvonne, a publisher who, along with her husband Robert, owns the guest house in which Alison and Noah stay (season 2) * [[Peter Friedman]] as Robert, Yvonne's husband (season 2) * Abigail Dylan Harrison as Stacey Solloway, Noah and Helen's youngest daughter (seasons 3–5) * [[Brendan Fraser]] as John Gunther, a prison guard (season 3) * Reagan and Savannah Grella as Joanie, Alison and Cole's daughter (seasons 3–4) * Christopher Meyer as Anton Gatewood, an intelligent student at the school where Noah teaches (season 4) * [[Russell Hornsby]] as Carl Gatewood, Janelle's ex-husband and Anton's father (seasons 4–5) * [[Emily Browning]] as Sierra, Helen and Vik's neighbor (seasons 4–5) * [[Ramón Rodríguez (actor)|Ramon Rodriguez]] as Ben Cruz, a [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] veteran and Alison's love interest (season 4) * Zenobia Shroff as Priya Ullah, Vik's mother (season 4) ==Production== On February 8, 2013, it was announced that [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] had ordered a pilot for ''The Affair''.{{Cite news|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title=Showtime Gives Pilot Order To 'Affair' |url=http://deadline.com/2013/02/showtime-gives-pilot-order-to-an-affair-425582/|accessdate=August 29, 2014|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=February 8, 2013}} The network officially picked up the series on January 16, 2014, with a 10-episode order. On November 10, 2014, Showtime renewed the series for a 10-episode second season;{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2014/11/10/homeland-season-5-renewed-the-affair-season-2/ |title=Showtime Renews ''Homeland'' for Season 5, ''The Affair'' for Season 2 |publisher=TVLine |first=Matt Webb |last=Mitovich |date=November 10, 2014 |accessdate=November 10, 2014}} however, it was later changed to 12.{{cite press |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2015/08/21/2015-showtime-fall-programming-overview-910314/20150821showtime01/ |title=2015 Showtime Fall Programming Overview |publisher=Showtime |date=August 21, 2015 |accessdate=September 27, 2015}} On December 9, 2015, the series was renewed for a third season.{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2015/12/09/homeland-renewed-season-6-showtime/ |title=''Homeland'', ''The Affair'' Renewed |publisher=TVLine |first=Michael |last=Ausiello |date=December 9, 2015 |accessdate=December 9, 2015}} On January 9, 2017, Showtime renewed the series for a fourth season.{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2017/01/09/the-affair-renewed-season-4-showtime/ |title=The Affair Renewed for Season 4 |publisher=TVLine |first=Kimberly |last=Roots |date=January 9, 2017 |accessdate=January 9, 2017}} On July 26, 2018, Showtime announced it had renewed the series for a fifth and final season.{{cite web |url=https://tvline.com/2018/07/26/the-affair-renewed-final-season-5-showtime/ |title=The Affair to End With Season 5 |publisher=TVLine |first=Michael |last=Ausiello |date=July 26, 2018 |accessdate=July 26, 2018}} After the conclusion of the fourth season and prior to the start of production on the fifth and final season, several series regulars departed the series. [[Ruth Wilson]] requested to leave ahead of season four, and her character was killed off at the end of the season.{{cite web |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/joshua-jackson-exit-affair-1147001 |title=Joshua Jackson's Days on 'The Affair' Are Numbered |work=The Hollywood Reporter |first=Lesley |last=Goldberg |date=September 25, 2018 |accessdate=October 21, 2018}} [[Joshua Jackson]], [[Catalina Sandino Moreno]] and [[Omar Metwally]] also will not return as series regulars for the final season. ==Reception== ===Critical response=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="float: right;text-align:center; width:%70;margin:10px” |- ! style="padding:0 8px;" colspan="2" rowspan="2" | Season ! style="padding:0 8px;" colspan="2" | Critical response |- ! style="padding:0 8px;" | [[Rotten Tomatoes]] ! style="padding:0 8px;" | [[Metacritic]] |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#B9D6D4;"| | 1 | 90% (50 reviews) | 85 (28 reviews) |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#899A98;"| | 2 | 90% (21 reviews) | 78 (15 reviews) |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#005E80;"| | 3 | 79% (19 reviews) | 72 (8 reviews) |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#DCDDB1;"| | 4 | 90% (21 reviews) | {{n/a}} |} The first season received praise from critics. On the review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the season has a rating of 90%, based on 50 reviews, with an average rating of 8.18/10. The consensus reads: "Thanks to some smart, creative storytelling and spectacular performances, ''The Affair'' is a somber, bewitching exploration of truth and desire."{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the-affair/s01/ |title=The Affair: Season 1 (2014) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=January 18, 2015}} On [[Metacritic]], the first season has a score of 85 out of 100, based on 28 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-affair |title=The Affair - Season 1 Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=October 18, 2014}} The second season received continued positive reviews from critics. On Rotten Tomatoes, the season has a rating of 90%, based on 21 reviews, with an average rating of 8.04/10. The consensus reads: "''The Affair'' shifts its emphasis in season two, moving psychological drama to the foreground and expanding the show's central crime story to include two new points of view."{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the-affair/s02/ |title=The Affair: Season 2 (2015) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=August 8, 2016}} On Metacritic, it has a score of 78 out of 100 based on 15 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-affair/season-2 |title=The Affair - Season 2 Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=October 4, 2015}} Gwen Ihnat of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave it an "A-" grade and wrote that "With its bold new move to double our number of perspectives, it appears that ''The Affair'' will sail over that sophomore slump that has felled so many other Showtime dramas.{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/review/emotional-drama-affair-gets-even-more-intimate-sea-226085 |title=Emotional drama ''The Affair'' gets even more intimate in season 2 |work=The A.V. Club |first=Gwen |last=Ihnat |date=October 2, 2015 |accessdate=October 4, 2015}} The third season received continued positive reviews from critics. On Rotten Tomatoes, the season has a rating of 79%, based on 19 reviews, with an average rating of 7.67/10. The consensus reads: "''The Affair'' adds to its cast of strong characters and deepens the mood, tension, and intrigue, even if the plot sometimes struggles to move forward."{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the_affair/s03/ |title=The Affair: Season 3 (2016) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=November 19, 2016}} On Metacritic, it has a score of 72 out of 100 based on 8 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-affair/season-3 |title=The Affair - Season 3 Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=November 19, 2016}} The fourth season received continued positive reviews from critics.{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-affair/season-4 |title=The Affair - Season 4 Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=June 19, 2018}} On Rotten Tomatoes, the season has a rating of 90%, based on 21 reviews, with an average rating of 7.8/10. The consensus reads: "''The Affair''{{'}}s captivating character study returns with fewer kinks than its previous outing, resulting in a more emotionally grounded season that regains much of the show's initial allure."{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the_affair/s04/ |title=The Affair: Season 4 (2018) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=June 19, 2018}} ===Awards and nominations=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Association ! Category ! Nominee(s) ! Rodriguez, ''Transparent'', ''The Affair'' Win Big |publisher=TVLine |first=Andy |last=Swift |date=January 11, 2015 |accessdate=January 12, 2015}} | [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television page.title: The Legend of the 7 Golden Vampires

revision.comment: /* External links */ I removed a redundant category.
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = The Legend of the 7 Golden Vampires | image = The-Legend-of-the-Seven-Golden-Vampires-poster.jpg | caption = UK theatrical release poster by [[Arnaldo Putzu]] | director = {{plainlist| * [[Roy Ward Baker]] }} | producer = {{plainlist| * [[Don Houghton]] * Vee King Shaw }} | writer = [[Don Houghton]] | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Peter Cushing]] * [[John Forbes-Robertson (actor)|John Forbes-Robertson]] * [[David Chiang]] * [[Robin Stewart]] * [[Julie Ege]] }} | music = [[James Bernard (composer)|James Bernard]] | cinematography = {{plainlist| * Roy Ford * [[John Wilcox (cinematographer)|John Wilcox]] }} | editing = Chris Barnes | studio = {{plainlist| * [[Hammer Film Productions]] * [[Shaw Brothers Studio]] }} | distributor = {{plainlist| * [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia]]-[[Warner Bros.|Warner Distributors]] (UK) * Shaw Brothers Studio (Hong Kong) * Dynamite Entertainment (US) }} | released = {{film date|df=yes|1974|7|11|Hong Kong|1974|10|6|UK}} | runtime = 83 minutes | country = {{plainlist| * United Kingdom * Hong Kong }} | language = English
Mandarin | budget = }} '''''The Legend of the 7 Golden Vampires''''' is a 1974 [[horror film]]/[[martial arts film]] produced by [[Hammer Film Productions]] and [[Shaw Brothers Studio]]. It is the ninth and final film in the Hammer ''Dracula'' series. It was released in the US by [[Dynamite Films]] in 1979 in a heavily edited version as '''''The 7 Brothers Meet Dracula''''', and was alternately known on the US trailer as '''''The 7 Brothers and their One Sister Meet Dracula'''''. In the [[ Far East]], it was titled '''''Dracula and the 7 Golden Vampires'''''. The film is notable for having an actor other than [[Christopher Lee]] portray [[Count Dracula]] in the Hammer ''Dracula'' series; before this film was made, Lee had left the role of the Count. The role of Dracula is played by [[John Forbes-Robertson (actor)|John Forbes-Robertson]] (though the actor's voice is dubbed by [[David de Keyser]]). ==Storyline== ===Prologue=== In Transylvania in 1804, a lone figure makes his way through the countryside and into the towering Castle Dracula. He heads over to the tomb of the legendary vampire before summoning him. Soon, Count Dracula appears from his crypt and demands to know who has disturbed him. The figure announces, in his own language, that his name is Kah, a [[Taoism|Taoist]] monk and the High Priest of the Temple of the Seven Golden Vampires in rural China. He goes on to tell the Count that the Seven Golden Vampires' power is fading and he needs him to restore them to their former glory. Dracula considers the offer and accepts on one condition: that he takes on Kah's body and image to escape his castle, which has become his prison. Despite Kah's pleas for mercy, the vampire takes hold of the monk in a cloud of unearthly mist and they are both subdued. When the mist clears, Kah speaks with the voice of Count Dracula, who then triumphantly leaves the tomb, bound for China... ===Plot=== In 1904 [[Abraham Van Helsing|Professor Van Helsing]] ([[Peter Cushing]]) gives a lecture at a [[Chongqing|Chungking]] university on Chinese [[vampire]] legends. He speaks of an unknown rural village that has been terrorised by a cult of seven known as the "Seven Golden Vampires" for many years. He goes on to explain that a simple farmer, armed with a pitchfork and who had lost his wife to the vampires, trekked his way to the temple of the vampires, where he saw many other unfortunate women strapped to tables, waiting for their blood to be drained. The farmer burst in and battled the vampires. He is unsuccessful as his wife is killed in the fight, but in the chaos, he grabbed a bat-like medallion from around one of the vampire's necks, which he sees as the vampires' life source. Defeated, the farmer flees the temple, but the High Priest orders the vampires after him. After they leave on horseback, the High Priest summons the vampire's former victims: the undead rise from their graves to aid the seven vampires. Still carrying the medallion, the farmer places it around a small model of a jade Buddha. He knocks desperately on the locked village gates, but it is in vain. The vampires and their undead catch up with him and kill him. One of the vampires spies the medallion around the Buddha and goes over to collect it. The moment the vampire touched the Buddha, the creature is destroyed in flames. Van Helsing goes on to say that he is positive the village still exists and is still terrorised by the six remaining vampires. He is only unsure of where the village lies. Most students disapprove of the story and leave. Back in Van Helsing's rented house, a student named Hsi Ching ([[David Chiang]]) informs him that the legend is true and that he knows the location of the village. He goes on to say that the farmer from the story was his grandfather. He proves it by producing the dead vampire's bat-like medallion. He then asks Van Helsing if he would be willing to travel to the village and destroy the vampire menace. Van Helsing agrees and embarks with his son Leyland ([[Robin Stewart]]), Hsi Ching, and his seven kung fu trained siblings on a dangerous journey, funded by a wealthy widow named Vanessa Buren ([[Julie Ege]]), who Leyland and two of Ching's siblings saved from an attack by the tongs. On the journey, they are ambushed by three of the six remaining vampires in a cave along with the undead. The group are quickly engaged in battle and soon kill the three vampires. The remaining three, sensing that they are outnumbered, are quick to retreat, taking their army of undead with them. The following morning, the party reach the village, partly ruined but still populated, and prepare to make their final stand. They use wooden stakes as barriers and dig a large trench around them filled with flammable liquid. In the temple that evening, Kah calls on the remaining vampires to kill Van Helsing and his party once and for all. The vampires ride on horseback, followed by their army of undead, to the village. The vampires reach the village, and soon, Van Helsing's group once again do battle with the last of the golden vampires and their undead, resulting in nearly all their party and the villagers being massacred. During the fight, Vanessa is bitten by one of the vampires and she quickly becomes one herself. She then seduces Ching and bites his neck. Knowing what he will become and what he has to do, Ching throws himself and Vanessa onto a wooden stake, impaling them both. Elsewhere, the last remaining vampire captures Mai Kwei ([[Shih Szu]]), Ching's sister, and takes her back to the temple to be drained of her blood. Seeing this, Leyland steals a horse from one of the dead vampires and pursues. The undead defeated, Van Helsing and his remaining party follow to help Leyland at the temple. Having reached the temple, the vampire straps Mai Kwei to one of the altars. It is about to drain her blood when Leyland leaps onto the creature's back and throws it to the ground, before freeing the sister. The vampire comes around and attacks Leyland, throwing him onto one of the altars in the struggle. Leyland is about to be drained when Van Helsing and his group burst in. Van Helsing thrusts a spear into the vampire's back, impaling it. Dying, the last of the golden vampires stumbles and collapses into a vat of boiling blood, where it quickly evaporates, leaving behind the bat-like medallion, its mask and a pile of dried blood and red dust. The survivors depart from the temple, save for Van Helsing, who feels a familiar atmosphere. Sure enough, a familiar voice bellows from behind him. Van Helsing turns around to face Kah the High Priest. Recognizing the voice, Van Helsing realises that Dracula has been using the form of the monk to control the seven golden vampires and their undead. Van Helsing demands Dracula to show himself, calling him a coward. Dracula reverts to his true form and attacks Van Helsing. In the ensuing struggle, Van Helsing succeeds in stabbing Dracula with a spear through the heart. Defeated, the Count collapses onto one of the altars and gradually decays to bones. The spear that killed him collapses, smashing the vampire's skull. Soon, there is nothing left of the Count, save for his dusty remains and the blood-stained spear. ==Cast== [[File:The 7 Brothers Meet Dracula.jpg|right|thumb|200px|John Forbes-Robertson as Dracula in the film]] * [[Peter Cushing]] as [[Abraham Van Helsing|Professor Van Helsing]] * [[John Forbes-Robertson (actor)|John Forbes-Robertson]] as [[Count Dracula]] * [[David de Keyser]] as the voice of Dracula (uncredited) * [[Robin Stewart]] as Leyland Van Helsing * [[Julie Ege]] as Vanessa Buren * Robert Hanna as British Consul * [[David Chiang]] as Hsi Ching/Hsi Tien-en * [[Shih Szu]] as Mai Kwei * Chan Shen as Kah the High Priest/Count Dracula's host * [[Lau Kar-wing]] as Hsi Kwei (archer) * Huang Pei-Chih as Hsi Po-Kwei (spearman) * Wang Chiang as Hsi San (twin swordsman) * Feng Ko-An as an assassin * Hsu Hsia as an assassin ==Production== Both [[Roy Ward Baker]], a British director who had helmed several previous Hammer films, and [[Chang Cheh]], a veteran Hong Kong action director, worked on the movie, though only Baker is credited. He took over the making of the film after [[Gordon Hessler]] left it weeks before. Filming was hard, as both Chinese and British crews had to work together despite the language barrier. ''The Legend of the 7 Golden Vampires'' was a co-production with Hong Kong's [[Shaw Brothers Studio]], made in the hope of garnering some of the [[kung fu (term)|kung fu]] movie market share. [[Michael Carreras]] later said this "wasn't such a good idea" although he felt "some of the film is quite good."{{Cite web|website=Fangoria|page=57|url=https://archive.org/stream/Fangoria_110_1992_Hellraider_3_DaveWooderson-DREGS_c2c#page/n58/mode/1up/search/%22nat+cohen%22+|date=1992|first=Steve|last=Swires|title=Fall of the House of Hammer}} The movie was released with various titles in different locations, including ''The 7 Brothers Meet Dracula'' in the US and ''Dracula and the 7 Golden Vampires'' in the Far East. During some scenes involving roving gangs of undead, several vampires can be seen hopping up and down, as vampires tend to do in Chinese vampire films. The US version trims twenty minutes of the film's footage and soundtrack and loops several remaining scenes to fill the running time. ==Reception== ===Critical=== Critical reaction to the film has been mixed. Keith Phipps of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' called the film "flawed" but "enjoyable," adding, "It's pretty much as ridiculous as it sounds, but there's something inherently entertaining about make-up-splattered vampires, distinguished British actors, and martial artists squaring off in periodic eruptions of kung-fu fighting." Phil Chandler of ''DVD Cult'' wrote, "Is it the best Hammer horror film ever made? Hell no. Is it the best Hammer film of the seventies? Hell yeah." Graeme Clark of ''The Spinning Image'' said, "Cushing, in his last Hammer Dracula film, is as commanding as ever, but he and his Western companions are pretty disposable to the plot until the end, where the professor is left alone with the Count, who is hardly needed. Nevertheless, this last Hammer vampire outing has a real energy, in spite of being a mishmash, and is different enough to get by on sheer novelty alone." Writing in ''The Zombie Movie Encyclopedia'', academic [[Peter Dendle]] called the raising of the undead army "one of the most visually spectacular in zombie cinema". Glenn Kay, who wrote ''[[Zombie Movies: The Ultimate Guide]]'', called the film "boisterous, action-packed, and very likeable". ===Box Office=== The film was not a box office success. There was a planned sequel, ''Kali: The Devil Bride of Dracula'' to be shot in India but it was not made.{{Cite web|website=Fangoria|page=57|url=https://archive.org/stream/Fangoria_110_1992_Hellraider_3_DaveWooderson-DREGS_c2c#page/n58/mode/1up/search/%22nat+cohen%22+|date=1992|first=Steve|last=Swires|title=Fall of the House of Hammer}} ==Home media== The US DVD from [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]] features both the edited ''The 7 Brothers Meet Dracula'' version, as well as the original unedited ''The Legend of the 7 Golden Vampires'' version. The DVD also features a recording of Peter Cushing telling the story of the film with music and sound effects, which was released as an [[LP record]] at the time of the film's release. https://www.blu-ray.com/The-Legend-of-the-7-Golden-Vampires/188240/#Overview ==See also== * [[Vampire film]] ==References== {{Reflist |refs= {{cite web|url=http://www.dvdcult.com/rev_7Vamps.htm |title=Legend of the Seven Golden Vampires DVD |first=Phil |last=Chandler |year=2001 |work=DVD Cult |publisher=DVDCULT.COM |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221231110/http://dvdcult.com/rev_7Vamps.htm |archivedate=21 December 2008 }} {{cite web | url = http://www.avclub.com/articles/legend-of-the-7-golden-vampires,19112/ | title = Legend of the 7 Golden Vampires | first = Keith | last = Phipps | year = 2002 | work = The A.V. Club | publisher = Onion Inc. | accessdate = 31 March 2012}} {{cite web | url = http://www.thespinningimage.co.uk/cultfilms/displaycultfilm.asp?reviewid=903 | title = Legend of the 7 Golden Vampires | first = Graeme | last = Clark | year = 2004 | work = The Spinning Image | publisher = Darren Jones | accessdate = 31 March 2012}} {{cite news | title = Dracula Goes Martial Arty | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ke5UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NZIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4818,6465069&dq=the-legend-of-the-7-golden-vampires&hl=en | newspaper = [[The Age]] | publisher = [[Fairfax Media]] | location = [[Melbourne]] | issn = 0312-6307 | oclc = 224060909 | date = 28 November 1974 | page = 21 | accessdate = 31 March 2012}} {{cite news | title = '7 Brothers Meet Dracula' in China | first = Linda | last = Gross | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/651143982.html?dids=651143982:651143982&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Sep+19%2C+1979&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc='7+Brothers+Meet+Dracula'+in+China&pqatl=google | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | publisher = Eddy Hartenstein | location = Los Angeles, California, US | issn = 0458-3035 | oclc = 3638237 | date = 19 September 1979 | page = G16 | accessdate = 31 March 2012}} {{cite book|title=The Zombie Movie Encyclopedia|last=Dendle|first=Peter|authorlink=Peter Dendle|publisher=[[McFarland & Company]]|year=2001|page=102|isbn=978-0-7864-9288-6}} {{cite book|title=Zombie Movies: The Ultimate Guide|last=Kay|first=Glenn|publisher=[[Chicago Review Press]]|year=2008|isbn=978-1-55652-770-8|pages=97}} }} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0070297}} * {{Amg movie|89950}} * {{tcmdb title|26765}} *[http://www.screenonline.org.uk/film/id/462731/index.html ''The Legend of the 7 Golden Vampires''] at [[BFI Screenonline]] {{Dracula}} {{Roy Ward Baker}} {{Chang Cheh}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Legend Of The 7 Golden Vampires, The}} [[Category:1974 films]] [[Category:1974 horror films]] [[Category:1970s fantasy films]] [[Category:Hong Kong revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''The Sound of Laughter''''' was British comedian [[Peter Kay]]'s initial volume of [[autobiography]], released on 5 October 2006. The book was a bestseller.<ref>{{cite book|author=Martin Wainwright|title=True North: In Praise of England's Better Half|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4hb-SE9Ra7IC&pg=PT244|date=5 June 2012|publisher=Guardian Books|isbn=978-0-85265-369-2|page=244}}</ref>
''The Sound of Laughter'' was a success with 278,000 copies sold in its first day (including pre-orders). It went straight in at Number 1 on both the [[Play.com]] and [[Amazon.co.uk]] book charts and was the Number 1 highest selling autobiography in the UK.
==Cover==
The cover of the book features Kay's head on [[Julie Andrews]]' body from ''[[The Sound of Music (film)|The Sound of Music]]''. The raised effect on the head is supposed to look as if it has been cut out and stuck on, which ties in with the homely feel of the book.
==Promotion==
Kay has only done one promotional appearance for the book on ''[[The Paul O'Grady Show]]''. On the show, Kay came on dressed as a nun, with a mask of his face over his ordinary face - a parody of the cover of the book. In the interview he criticised [[Billy Connolly]]'s biography, ''[[Billy (book)|Billy]]'', as well as making numerous jokes about his education by nuns. He said he had many nuns teaching him:
*[[Sister Sledge]] *[[Scissor Sisters|Sister Scissors]] *[[Sister Act 2]] *[[Systematic (band)|Sister Matic]] *[[Sisters Are Doin' It for Themselves|Sister Zar Doin-it]] *[[Swing Out Sister|Sister Swingout]] *[[Sisters of Mercy|Sister O'Mercy]]
He added that every year, he sent a Valentine's card to each nun from Jesus.
==Follow up book== It was announced by Kay at [[Jason Manford]]'s stand-up gig in [[City of Salford|Salford]], that he would be releasing another book to follow on from ''The Sound of Laughter''. This was later confirmed by Random House and '''''Saturday Night Peter''''' was released in Autumn 2009.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.peterkay.co.uk Official Site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sound of Laughter, The}} [[Category:2006 books]] [[Category:Show business memoirs]]
