revision.comment: clean up spacing around commas, replaced: ,t → , t
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} [[File:"Prove it with a Kodak".jpg|thumb|An early woman amateur photographer. Kodak advertisement from 1918]]
The participation of '''women in photography''' goes back to the very origins of the process. Several of the earliest women photographers, most of whom were from Britain or France, were married to male pioneers or had close relationships with their families. It was above all in northern Europe that women first entered the business of photography, opening studios in Denmark, France, Germany, and Sweden from the 1840s, while it was in Britain that women from well-to-do families developed photography as an art in the late 1850s. Not until the 1890s did the first studios run by women open in New York City.
Following Britain's [[The Linked Ring|Linked Ring]], which promoted artistic photography from the 1880s, [[Alfred Stieglitz]] encouraged several women to join the [[Photo-Secession]] movement which he founded in 1902 in support of so-called [[pictorialism]]. In Vienna, [[Dora Kallmus]] pioneered the use of photographic studios as fashionable meeting places for the Austro-Hungarian aristocracy.
In the United States, women first photographed as amateurs, several producing fine work which they were able to exhibit at key exhibitions. They not only produced portraits of celebrities and Native Americans but also took landscapes, especially from the beginning of the 20th century. The involvement of women in [[photojournalism]] also had its beginnings in the early 1900s but slowly picked up during [[World War I]].
==Early participants==
While the work of the English and French gentlemen involved in developing and pioneering the process of photography is well documented, the part played by women in the early days tends to be given less attention.<ref name="Newhall1982">{{cite book|last=Newhall|first=Beaumont|title=The history of photography: from 1839 to the present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q9xTAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=11 April 2013|year=1982|publisher=Museum of Modern Art|isbn=978-0-87070-381-2}}</ref>
===The beginnings===
Women were however involved in photography from the start. [[Constance Fox Talbot]], the wife of [[Henry Fox Talbot]], one of the key players in the development of photography in the 1830s and 1840s, had herself experimented with the process as early as 1839.<ref name="Buckland1980">{{cite book|last=Buckland|first=Gail|title=Fox Talbot and the invention of photography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OtBTAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=11 April 2013|year=1980|publisher=D. R. Godine|isbn=978-0-87923-307-5}}</ref> [[Richard Ovenden]] attributes to her a hazy image of a short verse by the Irish poet [[Thomas Moore]], which would make her the earliest known female photographer.<ref>Maev Kennedy, [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2012/dec/09/bodleian-library-bid-fox-talbot-archive "Bodleian Library launches £2.2m bid to stop Fox Talbot archive going overseas"], ''The Guardian'', 9 December 2012. Retrieved 11 April 2013.</ref>
[[Anna Atkins]], a botanist, was also introduced to photography by Fox Talbot, who explained his "photogenic drawing" technique to her as well as his camera-based [[calotype]] process. After learning about the [[cyanotype]] process from its inventor, [[John Herschel]], she was able to produce cyanotype [[photogram]]s of dried algae. She published them in 1843 in her ''Photographs of British Algae: Cyanotype Impressions'', said to be the first book with photographic illustrations.<ref name="AtkinsSchaaf1985">{{cite book|last1=Atkins|first1=Anna|last2=Schaaf|first2=Larry John|last3=Kraus|first3=Hans P.|title=Sun gardens: Victorian photograms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ld5TAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=11 April 2013|year=1985|publisher=Aperture|isbn=978-0-89381-203-4}}</ref>
Another botanist and keen amateur photographer, [[John Dillwyn Llewelyn]], was possibly introduced to photography by his wife Emma Thomasina Talbot, a cousin of Fox Talbot.<ref name="Marien2006">{{cite book|last=Marien|first=Mary Warner|title=Photography: A Cultural History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NsolmLbz8igC&pg=PA35|accessdate=11 April 2013|year=2006|publisher=Laurence King Publishing|isbn=978-1-85669-493-3|pages=35–}}</ref> His wife had shown an early interest in photography and did all his printing.<ref>Michael Pritchard, [http://www.mpritchard.com/photohistory/history/llewelyn.htm "Llewelyn, John Dillwyn"], Michael Pritchard. Retrieved 11 April 2013.</ref>
<gallery class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Anna Atkins algae cyanotype.jpg|[[Anna Atkins]]: "''[[Dictyota dichotoma]]'', in the young state; and in fruit" (cyanotype, 1843) File:Anna Atkins Cystoseira granulata.jpg|Anna Atkins: "''[[Cystoseira granulata]]''" (cyanotype, 1843) </gallery>
===The first professionals===
In France, [[Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri]] was an early professional in the photography business. Together with her husband, [[André-Adolphe-Eugène Disdéri]] who is remembered for patenting the [[carte de visite]] process, she established a [[daguerrotype]] studio in [[Brest, France|Brest]] in the late 1840s. After Disdéri left her for Paris in 1847, she continued to run the business alone.<ref>Kelly E. Wilder, [http://www.answers.com/topic/genevi-ve-lisabeth-disd-ri "Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri"], ''Oxford Companion to the Photograph''. Retrieved 12 April 2013.</ref> [[Bertha Wehnert-Beckmann]] was probably Germany's first professional female photographer. In 1843, she opened a studio in [[Leipzig]] together with her husband and ran the business herself after his death in 1847.<ref name=nicole>[http://www.dresden.de/media/pdf/gleichstellung/Strassennamen1.pdf Nicole Schönherr, ''Straßennamen in Dresden – Reine Männersache?''] Landeshauptstadt Dresden. Der Oberbürgermeister, Gleichstellungsbeauftragte für Frau und Mann, Dresden 2005, page 32. {{de icon}} Retrieved 12 April 2013.</ref> [[Emilie Bieber]] opened a daguerrotype studio in [[Hamburg]] in 1852. After a slow start, business picked up and she ran the studio until 1885 when she transferred it to her nephew.<ref name=Bake>[http://www.hamburg.de/clp/frauenbiografien-namensregister/clp1/hamburgde/onepage.php?BIOID=3209&qR=E&PR=1 Rita Bake, "Emilie Bieber"], Hamburg.de. {{de icon}} Retrieved 12 April 2013.</ref> In the United States, [[Sarah Louise Judd]] (1802–1886) is reported to have made daguerrotypes in [[Minnesota]] as early as 1848.<ref name="PalmquistKailbourn2005">{{cite book|last1=Palmquist|first1=Peter E.|last2=Kailbourn|first2=Thomas R.|title=Pioneer Photographers from the Mississippi to the Continental Divide: A Biographical Dictionary, 1840–1865|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UNipzykMBEIC&pg=PA366|accessdate=22 March 2013|year=2005|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-4057-9|pages=366–}}</ref>
[[Thora Hallager]], one of Denmark's earliest women photographers, probably practiced in [[Copenhagen]] from the beginning of the 1850s. She is however remembered above all for the fine portrait of [[Hans Christian Andersen]] she took in 1869.<ref>[http://www.tidsskrift.dk/index.php/fundogforskning/article/view/1604/2658 Tove Hansen, "Kvinders fotografi Kvindelige fotografer i Danmark før 1900"], ''Fund og Forskning'', Vol 29 (1990). {{da icon}} Retrieved 12 April February 2013.</ref> In Sweden too, women entered the photography business at an early stage. [[Brita Sofia Hesselius]] performed [[Daguerreotype]] photography in [[Karlstad]] as early as 1845,<ref>Värmland förr och nu 1984. Karlstad framför kameran. Bromander, Carl Wilhelm: Från dagerrotypi till kamerakonst. Ett yrkes åttioårshistoria i Karlstad.</ref> and [[Marie Kinnberg]] was one of the very first to use the new photographic technique in Gothenburg in 1851-52.<ref name="ReferenceA">Dahlman, Eva: Kvinnliga pionjärer, osynliga i fotohistorien</ref>
[[Hilda Sjölin]] became a professional photographer in [[Malmö]] in 1860, opening a studio there the following year,<ref>[http://malmomuseer.se/thumbnails.php?album=26 "Hilda Sjölin"], Malmö Museer. {{se icon}} Retrieved 12 April 2013</ref> while [[Sofia Ahlbom]] also included photography among the arts she practiced in the 1860s.<ref>[http://runeberg.org/sqvinnor/0012.html Wilhelmina Stålberg, P. G. Berg, "Sofia Ahlbom"], "Anteckningar om svenska qvinnor" (1864). {{se icon}} Retrieved 12 April 2013.</ref> In 1864, [[Bertha Valerius]] in Stockholm became official photographer of the Royal Swedish court (later followed as such by her student [[Selma Jacobsson]]). During the 1860s, they were at least 15 confirmed female photographers in Sweden, three of whom, [[Rosalie Sjöman]], [[Caroline von Knorring]] and Bertha Valerius belonging to the elite of their profession. In 1888, the first woman, Anna Hwass, became a member of the board of the Photographic Society.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
In Switzerland, [[Alwina Gossauer]] (1841–1926) became one of the first women professional photographers.<ref name="fotostiftung">{{cite web|url=http://www.fotostiftung.ch/de/archive-spezialsammlungen/index-der-fotografinnen/fotografin/?no_cache=1&tx_mssccumulus_msscphotographerlist%5Bfotograf%5D=1746&tx_mssccumulus_msscphotographerlist%5BimgId%5D=&tx_mssccumulus_msscphotographerlist%5Bletter%5D=G&tx_mssccumulus_msscphotographerlist%5Baction%5D=show&tx_mssccumulus_msscphotographerlist%5Bcontroller%5D=Photographer&cHash=e239a32ff866cd45feb51d628a037ec7|title=Gossauer, Alwina|publisher=fotostiftung.ch|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="foto-ch">{{cite web|url=http://www.foto-ch.ch/?a=fotograph&id=22628&lang=it|title=Gossauer, Alwina|publisher=foto-ch.ch|author=Marc Herren|language=German|date=2015-04-08|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref>
<gallery class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Genevieve Elisabeth Disderi Cimetiere de Plougastel 1856.jpg|[[Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri]]: Cimetière de Plougastel (1856) File:Atelier Wehnert-Beckmann.jpg|[[Bertha Wehnert-Beckmann]]: The Wehnert-Beckmann studio (c. 1850) File:Hilda Sjölin Ida Hultgren 1863.jpg|[[Hilda Sjölin]]: Portrait of Ida Hultgren (1863) File:Niels Frederik Larsen 1863 by S. Degen & Th. Hallager.jpg|[[Thora Hallager]]: Niels Frederik Larsen (1863) File:HCA by Thora Hallager 1869.jpg|Thora Hallager: Hans Christian Andersen (1869) </gallery>
===Pioneering artists=== Two British ladies are remembered for their early contributions to artistic photography. In the late 1850s, [[Lady Clementina Hawarden]] began to take photographs. The earliest images were landscapes taken on the Hawarden estate in [[Dundrum, County Tipperary|Dundrum]], Ireland. After the family moved to London, in 1862 she converted the first floor of her [[South Kensington]] home into a studio, filling it with props which can be seen in her photographs. She specialised in portraits, especially of her two eldest daughters clad in the costumes of the day. Her work earned her silver medals at the exhibitions of the [[Royal Photographic Society|Photographic Society]] in 1863 and 1864.<ref>[http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/pictures/the-scottish-aristocrat-whose-pioneering-photography-drew-admiration-from-lewis-carroll-1-2778249 Mike Merritt, "The Scottish aristocrat whose pioneering photography drew admiration from Lewis Carroll"], ''The Scotsman'', 7 February 2013. Retrieved 13 April 2013.</ref> Even more widely recognized for pioneering artistic work is [[Julia Margaret Cameron]]. Although her interest in photography did not begin until 1863 when she was 48 years old, she consciously set out to ensure photography became an acceptable art form, taking hundreds of portraits of children and celebrities. While her commitment to soft focus was frequently criticized as technically deficient during her lifetime, it later formed the basis for the [[Pictorialism]] movement at the beginning of the 20th century and is now widely appreciated.<ref>[http://www.cmp.ucr.edu/collections/permanent/object_genres/photographers/women/cameron.html "Artistic Portraiture: Julia Margaret Cameron"], Woman Photographers, UCR/California Museum of Photography. Retrieved 13 April 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.sfmoma.org/exhib_events/exhibitions/524 "Julia Margaret Cameron's Women"], San Francisco Museum of Art. Retrieved 13 April 2013.</ref> [[Caroline Emily Nevill]] and her two sisters exhibited at the [[Royal Photographic Society|London Photographic Society]] in 1854 and went on to contribute architectural views of Kent with waxed-paper negatives.<ref>[http://www.luminous-lint.com/app/photographer/Caroline_Emily__Nevill/A/ "Caroline Emily Nevill"], Luminous Lint. Retrieved 7 May 2013.</ref> In Italy, [[Virginia Oldoini, Countess of Castiglione|Virginia Oldoini]], a mistress of [[Napoleon III]], became interested in photography in 1856, recording the signature moments of her life in hundreds of self-portraits, often wearing theatrical costumes.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Munhall|first1=Edgar|last2=Whistler|first2=James McNeill|last3=Collection|first3=Frick|title=Whistler and Montesquiou: the butterfly and the bat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tIhQAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=30 April 2013|year=1995|publisher=Frick Collection|page=42}}</ref>
<gallery class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Clementina Hawarden, Clementina Maude and Isabella, 1861.jpg|[[Clementina Hawarden]]: Her costumed daughters Clementina Maude and Isabella (1861) File:Clementina Hawarden, Clementina Maude.jpg|Clementina Hawarden: Clementina Maude in a dramatic posture (c. 1862) File:Sadness, by Julia Margaret Cameron.jpg|[[Julia Margaret Cameron]]: "Sadness" (1864) File:Charles Darwin by Julia Margaret Cameron.jpg|Julia Margaret Cameron: Portrait of Charles Darwin (1868) File:Blackberry Gathering, by Julia Margaret Cameron.jpg|Julia Margaret Cameron: "Blackberry Gathering" (c. 1869) </gallery>
===Studio work in the 19th century=== A number of [[Denmark|Danish]] women were quick to open their own studios. [[Frederikke Federspiel]] (1839–1913), who had learnt photography with her family in [[Hamburg]], opened a studio in [[Aalborg]] in the mid-1870s.<ref>[http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/597/bio/754/origin/170/ "Frederikke Federspiel (1839–1913)"], ''Dansk Kvindebiografisk Leksikon.'' {{dk icon}} Retrieved 30 April 2013.</ref> [[Mary Steen]] opened her [[Copenhagen]] studio in 1884 when she was only 28, soon becoming Denmark's first female court photographer with portraits of [[Alexandra of Denmark|Princess Alexandra]] in 1888.<ref>[http://www.kvinfo.dk/side/597/bio/1617/origin/170/ Tove Thage, "Mary Steen"], ''Dansk Kvindebiografisk Leksikon.'' {{dk icon}} Retrieved 30 April 2013.</ref> [[Benedicte Wrensted]] (1859–1949) opened a studio in [[Horsens]] in the 1880s before emigrating to the United States where she photographed Native Americans in [[Idaho]].<ref name="Rosinante">Aase Bak, "Benedicte Wrensted", in Sys Hartmann (ed.), ''Weilbachs Kunstnerleksikon'', København: Rosinante 1994–2000. {{Da icon}} Online [https://www.kulturarv.dk/kid/VisWeilbach.do?kunstnerId=11466&wsektion=alle here]. Retrieved 30 April 2013.</ref>
After studying photography at the [[London Polytechnic]], [[Alice Hughes]] (1857–1939) opened a studio in [[Gower Street, London]], in 1891, quickly becoming a leading photographer of royalty, fashionable women and children. At the height of her career, she employed 60 women and took up to 15 sittings a day.<ref name=bloomsbury>[http://www.ucl.ac.uk/bloomsbury-project/institutions/photographic_studio_gower.htm "Photographic Studio"], UCL Bloomsbury project. Retrieved 8 May 2013.</ref> In Japan, [[Shima Ryū]] together with her husband [[Shima Kakoku]], opened a studio in Tokyo around 1866.<ref>Bennett, Terry. ''Photography in Japan: 1853–1912'', Rutland, Vermont: Charles E. Tuttle, 2006. {{ISBN|0-8048-3633-7}}.</ref> In New Zealand, [[Elizabeth Pulman]] assisted her husband George with work in his [[Auckland]] studio from 1867. After his death in 1871, she continued to run the business until shortly before she died in 1900.<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/biographies/2p32/pulman-elizabeth "Pulman, Elizabeth"], ''Dictionary of New Zealand Biography''. Retrieved 7 May 2013.</ref>
One of the first female photographers to open a studio in New York City was [[Alice Boughton]] who had studied both art and photography at the [[Pratt School of Art and Design]]. In 1890, she opened a studio on East [[23rd Street (Manhattan)|23rd Street]] becoming one of the city's most distinguished portrait photographers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://brookhavensouthhaven.org/history/Boughton/BoughtonAlicObituaryAdvance.htm|title=Obituary for Alice Boughton|accessdate=5 July 2013|work=Long Island Advance |date=23 June 1943|publisher=Brookhaven and South Haven Hamlets }}</ref> [[Zaida Ben-Yusuf]], of German and Algerian descent, emigrated from Britain to the United States in 1895. She established a portrait studio on New York' s [[Fifth Avenue]] in 1897 where she photographed celebrities.<ref name=ne>[http://www.america.gov/st/arts-english/2008/May/20080429174122GLnesnoM0.9014856.html New Exhibition Resurrects Legacy of Groundbreaking Photographer: Ben-Yusuf produced memorable portraits that captured an era] published 2 May 2008, www.america.gov. Retrieved 7 May 2013.</ref>
<gallery class="center" widths="130" heights="160"> File:Mary Steen Victoria Beatrice Windsor 1895.jpg|[[Mary Steen]]: Queen Victoria with Princess Beatrice at Windsor Castle (1895) File:Federikke Federspiel with client 1910.jpg|[[Frederikke Federspiel]] with a client in her Aalborg studio (1910) File:Pauline-Astor-1904.jpg|[[Alice Hughes]]: Pauline Waldorf Astor (1904) File:RewiManiapoto1879.jpg|[[Elizabeth Pulman]]: Rewi Manga Maniapoto (1879) File:Minnie Maddern Fiske, seated, Zaida Ben-Yusuf, 1896 (crop).jpg|[[Zaida Ben-Yusuf]]: ''Mrs. Fiske, 'Love finds the way''' (1896) </gallery>
===History of Female Photographers in America===
Prior to the roaring twenties there were little to non female photographers in existence. After the huge advancement in culture after the roaring twenties the number of photographers that were women increase drastically. Estimated to be about 5,000 female photographers. Despite there still being an apparent line of gender limitations photography allowed for females to bring forth their creativity. Along came with many different opportunities including different publications such as "American Amateur Photographer" that allowed for women photographers whether she was an amateur or not to further showcase their skills. With no longer being labeled as "a wife of a photographer" women who already have a keen eye for the fashionable side of things photographer seem to be strong suit for them.The emergence of women in photography can be attributed to the progressive era. Where the roles of women in our every day society were changed tremendously and reversed. This time period a vast number of women photographers were reportedly apart of photography organizations.
==The pictorialists== {{See also|Pictorialism}} The use of photography as an art form had existed almost from the very beginning but it was towards the end of the 19th and the beginning of the 20th century that under the influence of the American [[Alfred Stieglitz]] its artistic potential, termed [[pictorialism]], became widely recognized.<ref>[http://www.artsmia.org/get-the-picture/print/stieglitz.shtml "Get the Picture: Alfred Stieglitz"], Minneapolis Institute of Arts. Retrieved 8 May 2013.</ref> Among Stieglitz' closest associates were [[Gertrude Käsebier]] (1852–1934) and [[Eva Watson-Schütze]] (1867–1935) who had turned to photography after studying fine art and were committed to developing artistic photography. Their association with Stieglitz led in 1902 to their becoming co-founders of the [[Photo-Secession]] movement. They went on to take romantic, yet well composed portraits which were presented at influential exhibitions.<ref>[http://www.cmp.ucr.edu/collections/permanent/object_genres/photographers/women/pictorialism.html "Gertrude Kasebier"], Women Photographers, UCR/California Museum of Photography. Retrieved 8 May 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.nmwa.org/explore/artist-profiles/eva-watson-sch%C3%BCtze "Eva Watson-Schütze"], National Museum of Women in the Arts. Retrieved 8 May 2013.</ref> In addition, Käsebier is remembered for her portraits of Native Americans, soon becoming one of the most widely recognized professional photographers in the United States.<ref>[http://segonku.unl.edu/~rwingo/ "'I shall be glad to see them': Gertrude Käsebier's Show Indian Photographs"]. Retrieved 8 May 2013.</ref> Other prominent pictorialists included Käsebier's assistant Alice Boughton and [[Anne Brigman]] (1869–1950) with her images of nude women.<ref>[http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artMakerDetails?maker=1760&page=1 "Anne W. Brigman"], The J. Paul Getty Museum. Retrieved 8 May 2013.</ref> [[Mary Devens]] (1857–1920) who experimented with printing techniques was like Käsebier elected a member of the British [[The Linked Ring|Linked Ring]] which has preceded Photo-Secession in promoting photography as an art form.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Homer|first1=William Innes|last2=Johnson|first2=Catherine|title=Stieglitz and the Photo-Secession, 1902|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zt9TAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=8 May 2013|year=2002|publisher=Viking Studio|isbn=978-0-670-03038-5}}</ref> The German-born Canadian [[Minna Keene]] (1861–1943) was also an early female member of the Linked Ring.<ref>[http://cwahi.concordia.ca/sources/artists/displayArtist.php?ID_artist=5629 "Keene, Minna"], Canadian Women Artists History Initiative. Retrieved 8 May 2013.</ref>
<gallery class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Chief Iron Tail, Gertrude Kasebier, 1898.jpg|[[Gertrude Käsebier]]: ''Chief Iron Tail'' (1898) File:Watson-Schutze Study Head.jpg|[[Eva Watson-Schütze]]: ''A Study Head'' (1900) File:Brigman.jpg|[[Anne Brigman]]: ''Soul of the Blasted Pine'' (1908) File:NesbitKasebier.jpg|Gertrude Käsebier: ''Miss N'', portrait of Evelyn Nesbit (1903) File:Alice boughton two women under a tree.jpg|[[Alice Boughton]]: ''Two Women under a Tree'' (1906) </gallery>
==Women photographers from Vienna== In prewar [[Vienna]], probably more than in any other European city, photo studios managed by women, especially Jewish women, greatly outnumbered those run by men. In all, some 40 women had studios in the city but the most famous of them all was undoubtedly [[Dora Kallmus]] (1881–1963).<ref>[http://www.timesofisrael.com/events/viennas-shooting-girls-jewish-women-photographers-from-vienna/ "Vienna’s Shooting Girls — Jewish Women Photographers from Vienna"], ''The Times of Israel''. Retrieved 13 May 2013.</ref> Known as Madame d'Ora, she became a member of the Vienna Photographic Society in 1905 and opened a studio there in 1907. After gaining success with the Austro-Hungarian aristocracy, she opened a second studio in Paris together with her colleague Arthur Benda, dominating the society and fashion photography scene in the 1930s. In addition to their photographic role, Dora Kallmus' studios became fashionable meeting places for the intellectual elite.<ref>[http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/madame-dora Lisa Silverman, "Madame d'Ora"], ''Jewish Women Encyclopedia''. Retrieved 13 May 2013.</ref> Other female photographers who embarked on successful careers in Vienna included [[Trude Fleischmann]] (1895–1990), who gained fame with a nude series of the dancer Claire Bauroff before moving on to New York,<ref name=austria>[http://austria-forum.org/af/Wissenssammlungen/Biographien/Fleischmann,_Trude "Fleischmann, Trude"], Austria-Forum. {{de icon}} Retrieved 13 May 2013.</ref> and [[Claire Beck Loos|Claire Beck]] (1904–1942) who died in a Nazi concentration camp in [[Riga]].<ref>[http://cafemarquardt.blogspot.com/2013/02/claire-beck-loos_22.html "Claire Beck-Loos und Adolf Loos"], Café Marquardt. {{de icon}} Retrieved 13 May 2013.</ref> [[Margaret Michaelis-Sachs]] (1902–1985), who eventually emigrated to Australia, also embarked on her photographic career in Vienna. She is remembered for her scenes of the Jewish market in [[Krakow]] taken in the 1930s.<ref>[http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/michaelis-margarethe-14956 Helen Ennis, "Michaelis, Margarethe (1902–1985)"], ''Australian Dictionary of Biography''. Retrieved 13 May 2013.</ref> Lotte Meitner-Graf
===Landscapes and street photography=== [[Sarah Ladd]] (1860–1927) began taking landscape photographs in [[Oregon]] at the end of the 19th century. Her images of the [[Columbia River]] which she developed in a darkroom on a houseboat were exhibited in 2008 at the [[Portland Art Museum]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Terry|last=Toedtemeier|title=Wild Beauty: Photographs of the Columbia River Gorge, 1867–1957|publisher=Corvallis: Oregon State University Press|year=2008 | isbn=978-0-87071-418-4 }}</ref> British-born [[Evelyn Cameron]] (1868–1928) took an extensive series of remarkably clear images of [[Montana]] and its people at the end of the 19th century. Rediscovered in the 1970s, they were published in book form as ''Photographing Montana 1894–1928: The Life and Work of Evelyn Cameron''.<ref>[http://visitmt.com/listing/categories_NET/City.aspx?CityID=326&SiteID=129 "Terry"], Visit Montana. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref>
[[Laura Gilpin]] (1891–1979), mentored by [[Gertrude Käsebier]], is remembered for her images of Native Americans and Southwestern landscapes, especially those taken in the 1930s.<ref>[http://www.cla.purdue.edu/waaw/sandweiss/ Martha A. Sandweiss, "Laura Gilpin and the Tradition of American Landscape Photography"], Women Artists of the American West. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Berenice Abbott]] (1898–1991) is best known for her black-and-white photography of New York City from 1929 to 1938. Much of the work was created under the [[Federal Art Project]]; a selection was first published in book form in 1939 as ''Changing New York''.<ref group="n">The book, with text by Elizabeth McCausland, was republished in 1973 as ''New York in the Thirties''; in 1997 a much larger selection was published as ''Berenice Abbott: Changing New York.''</ref> It has provided a historical chronicle of many now-destroyed buildings and neighborhoods of [[Manhattan]].<ref>[http://digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/explore/?col_id=160 "Changing New York: Photographs by Berenice Abbott, 1935–1938"], New York Public Library. Retrieved 17 May 2013.</ref>
<gallery class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Cameron Alec Flower Montana 1898.jpg|[[Evelyn Cameron]]: Alec Flower, her brother (1898) File:SarahLadd-EarlyMorning.jpg|[[Sarah Ladd]]: ''Early Morning above Vancouver'' (1905) File:Mission Church Taos LC-USZC4-3921.jpg|[[Laura Gilpin]]: Mission Church at Rancho de Taos (1930) File:Blossom Restaurant; 103 Bowery by Berenice Abbott in 1935.jpg|[[Berenice Abbott]]: Blossom Restaurant, New York (1935) </gallery>
===Photojournalism and documentary work=== Canadian-born [[Jessie Tarbox Beals|Jessie Tarbox]] (1870–1942) is credited with being America's earliest female photojournalist, photographing the Massachusetts state prison for the ''[[Boston Post]]'' in 1899. She was then hired by ''The Buffalo Inquirer'' and ''The Courier'' in 1902.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/rr/print/coll/womphotoj/bealsessay.html "Jessie Tarbox Beals (1870–1942)]", The Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Reading Room. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Harriet Chalmers Adams]] (1875–1937) was an explorer whose expedition photographs were published in [[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]. She served as a correspondent for [[Harper's Magazine]] in Europe during [[World War I]], the only female journalist permitted to visit the trenches.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/8-unsung-women-explorers-180658286.html "8 Unsung Women Explorers"], Yahoo News, 30 April 2012. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> Another war correspondent based in France during World War I was [[Helen Johns Kirtland]] (1890–1979) where she worked for ''[[Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper|Leslie's Weekly]]''.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/rr/print/coll/womphotoj/kirtlandresources.html "Helen Johns Kirtland (1890–1979): Biographical Essay"], Library of Congress. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref>
[[Margaret Bourke-White]] (1906–1971) was the first foreigner to photograph Soviet industry as well as the first female war correspondent and the first woman photographer to work for [[Life (magazine)|Life]].<ref>[http://www.lkwdpl.org/wihohio/bour-mar.htm "Margaret Bourke-White"], ''Women in History''. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> During the [[Great Depression]], [[Dorothea Lange]] (1895–1965) was employed by the [[Resettlement Administration]] to photograph displaced farm families and migrant workers. Distributed free to newspapers, her images became icons of the times.<ref>[http://www.crmagazine.org/archive/SpringSummer2010/Pages/DorotheaLangeEsophagealCancer.aspx Corinna Wu, "American Eyewitness"], ''CR Magazine''. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> The novelist [[Eudora Welty]] also photographed families affected by the Great Depression, especially in rural Mississippi, producing a remarkable body of work.<ref>[http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/The-Writers-Eye.html T.A. Frail, "Eudora Welty as Photographer"], ''Smithsonian magazine'', April 2009. Retrieved 20 May 2013.</ref> In the early 1930s, [[Marvin Breckinridge Patterson]] (1905–2002) published her world travel photographs in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'', ''[[Look (American magazine)|Look]]'', ''[[Life magazine|Life]]'', ''[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]]'', and ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]''.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/exhibits/wcf/wcf0009.html "Women Come to the Front: Marvin Breckinridge Patterson"], Library of Congress. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Marion Carpenter]] (1920–2002) was the first female national press photographer and the first woman to cover the [[White House]].<ref>[http://www.whnpa.org/about/carpenter.htm "Remembering Marion Carpenter"], Associated Press, 25 January 2002. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Edie McKee Harper|Edie Harper]] (1922-2010) was an [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Army Corps of Engineers]] photographer during WWII, where she took photographs of different structures on the home front, such as hydro dams and cement test samples. Edie processed the film in the lab for the Corps of Engineers.<ref>Bauer, Marilyn (August 4, 2002). "Cincinnati Modernists Reunited". The Cincinnati Enquirer.</ref> Photographs from her war work became highly acclaimed and were shown in an exhibition at the Cincinnati Contemporary Art Center in 1961.<ref>"Visionary Artists at the Carnegie Arts Center :: AEQAI". aeqai.com. Retrieved 2017-03-11</ref><ref>Villarreal, Ignacio. "Discover the Art of Cincinnati's Own Charley and Edie Harper at the Cincinnati Art Museum". artdaily.com. Retrieved 2017-03-11.</ref>
[[Mary Ellen Mark]] (March 20, 1940 – May 25, 2015) was an American photographer known for her [[photojournalism]] / [[documentary photography]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/27/mary-ellen-mark|title=Mary Ellen Mark obituary|last=O'Hagan|first=Sean|date=2015-05-27|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-03-11|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> portraiture, and advertising<ref name="nytimes-grimes">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/27/arts/design/mary-ellen-mark-photographer-who-documented-difficult-subjects-dies-at-75.html|title=Mary Ellen Mark, Photographer Who Documented Difficult Subjects, Dies at 75|last=Grimes|first=William|date=26 May 2015|accessdate=28 May 2015|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref name="huffingtonpost-dobnik">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/26/mary-ellen-mark-dead_n_7446878.html|title=Beloved Documentary Photographer Mary Ellen Mark Dies At 75|last=Dobnik|first=Verena|date=26 May 2015|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=28 May 2015}}</ref> as well as filmmaker. Her specialty was documenting from marginalized communities who were "away from mainstream society and toward its more interesting, often troubled fringes"<ref name="salon">[http://www.salon.com/people/bc/2000/03/28/mark/ Long, Andrew. "Brilliant Careers: Mary Ellen Mark"], ''[[Salon.com|Salon]]'', March 28, 2000</ref> She had 18 publications produced, most notably ''Streetwise''<ref name="independent-saul">{{cite news | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/mary-ellen-mark-renowned-documentary-photographer-dies-aged-75-10278354.html | date = 27 May 2015 | accessdate = 28 May 2015 | first = Heather | last = Saul | newspaper = [[The Independent]] | location = London | title = Mary Ellen Mark: Renowned documentary photographer dies aged 75}}</ref> that also became a documentary with [[Martin Bell (director)|Martin Bell]] and ''Ward 81''.<ref name="ohagan-guardian-obit">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/27/mary-ellen-mark | date = 27 May 2015 | accessdate = 27 May 2015 | first = Sean | last = O'Hagan | authorlink = Sean O'Hagan (journalist) | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | title = Mary Ellen Mark obituary}}</ref>[http://www.maryellenmark.com/text/magazines/american%20photographer/911T-000-001.html]<ref name="time-obituary-laurent">{{cite news | url = http://time.com/3896572/mary-ellen-mark-dies-at-75/ | date = May 26, 2015 | accessdate = May 26, 2015 | first = Olivier | last = Laurent | magazine = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | title = In Memoriam: Mary Ellen Mark (1940–2015)}}</ref> For ''Ward 81'' (1979), she lived for six weeks with the patients in the women’s security ward of [[Oregon State Hospital]]. Her photos can be found in major magazines in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[New York Times]]'', and ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]''. In 1977 to 1998, she became a member of [[Magnum Photos]]. Besides receiving [[Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award]]s, three fellowships from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], the 2014 Lifetime Achievement in Photography Award from the [[George Eastman House]] and the Outstanding Contribution Photography Award from the [[World Photography Organisation]], she received many other awards of recognition.
<gallery class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Lange-MigrantMother02.jpg|[[Dorothea Lange]]: ''Migrant Mother'' (1936) File:Tarbox William Howard Taft Governor-General of the Philippines.jpg|[[Jessie Tarbox Beals]]: William Howard Taft at the St. Louis World's Fair (1904) File:Treaty of Versailles Signing, Hall of Mirrors.jpg|[[Helen Johns Kirtland]]: Signing of the Treaty of Versailles in the Hall of Mirrors (1919) File:Rio de Janeiro's waterfront, 1919.jpg|[[Harriet Chalmers Adams]]: ''Rio de Janeiro's waterfront and the Morro de Castello from the Ilha das Cobras'' (1919) File:US-Luftbild 1945 Würzburg Domstr. m b-w 4892665549.jpg|[[Margaret Bourke-White]]: Aerial photo of the inner city of the destroyed Wurzburg (1945) </gallery>
==Surrealism== A number of women used photography as a medium for expressing their interest in [[Surrealism]]. [[Claude Cahun]] (1894–1954) from France is remembered for her highly staged self-portraits which she began taking in the 1920s.<ref>Kate Salter, [http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/news-features/TMG3363979/Claude-Cahun-The-surreal-deal.html "Claude Cahun: The surreal deal"], ''The Telegraph'', 6 January 2008. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> Croatian-born [[Dora Maar]] (1907–1997) also developed her interest in Surrealism in France, associating with [[André Breton]] and others. Her vivid portraits from the early 1930s bring out the features of the face as if drawn by an artist.<ref>[http://www.newyorkartworld.com/reviews/maar.html Donald Goddard, "Dora Maar: Photographer"], ''New York Art World''. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> The American [[Lee Miller]] (1907–1977) combined her fashion photography with Surrealism, associating with [[Pablo Picasso]] in Paris before returning to New York. She created some of the most striking nude photographs of the times.<ref>[http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/l/lee-miller/ "Lee Miller"], V&A. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref>
Surrealism continued to attract the interest of women photographers in the second half of the 20th century. [[Henriette Grindat]] (1923–1986) was one of the few Swiss women to develop an interest in artistic photography, associating with André Breton and later collaborating with [[Albert Camus]], with whom she published images of the [[Sorgue|River Sorgue]] in the south of France.<ref>[http://lejournaldelaphotographie.com/entries/4942/henriette-grindat-ou-l-anticonformisme "Henriette Grindat or the nonconformist"], ''Journal de la Photographie''. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> From the late 1940s, The Czech [[Emila Medková]] (1928–1985) began producing surrealistic works in 1947, above all remarkable documentary images of the urban environment in the oppressive post-war years.<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/research/publications/tate-papers/emila-medkova-magic-despair Krzysztof Fijałkowski, "Emila Medková: The Magic of Despair"], Tate, 1 October 2005. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> Though not strictly a Surrealist, the notable Mexican photographer [[Lola Álvarez Bravo]] (1907–1993) displayed elements of Surrealism throughout her career, especially in her portraits of [[Frida Kahlo]] and [[María Izquierdo (artist)|María Izquierdo]].<ref>[http://www.manchestergalleries.org/angelsofanarchy/resources/artists "Artist Biographies: Lola Alvarez Bravo"], Manchester Galleries. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref> During her short life [[Francesca Woodman]] (1958–1981), influenced by André Breton and [[Man Ray]], explored the relationship between the body and its surroundings often appearing partly hidden in her black-and-white prints.<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/francesca-woodman-10512 "Francesca Woodman 1958–1981"], Tate. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref>
==Evolving American participation== Peter E. Palmquist who researched the history of women photographers in California and the American West from 1850 to 1950 found that in the 19th century some 10% of all photographers in the area were women while by 1910 the figure was up to about 20%. In the early days, most women working commercially were married to a photographer. Indeed, up to 1890, any woman working on her own was considered to be daring. As the process became easier to handle, more amateurs emerged, many participating in photographic organizations.<ref>[http://www.cla.purdue.edu/WAAW/palmquist/Essays.htm#e21 Peter E. Palmquist, "Preface"], ''Women in Photography Archive''. Retrieved 14 May 2013.</ref>
In the 20th century, according to scholars, it was hard for women to become successful photographers.<ref name="auto">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/36589970|title=Silent witnesses : representations of working-class women in the United States|last=1969-|first=Ellis, Jacqueline,|date=1998|publisher=Bowling Green State University Popular Press|isbn=9780879727444|location=Bowling Green, OH|oclc=36589970}}</ref>
===Portraits=== [[Marian Hooper Adams]] (1843–1885) was one of America's earliest [[portrait photography|portrait photographers]] taking portraits of family, friends and politicians from 1883 and doing all the developing herself.<ref>[http://www.masshist.org/findingaids/doc.cfm?fa=fap007 "Marian Hooper Adams Photographs"], Massachusetts Historical Society. Retrieved 14 May 2013.</ref> [[Sarah Choate Sears]] (1858–1935) gained international attention as an amateur photographer after she began producing fine portraits and flower studies. She soon became a member of London's [[The Linked Ring|Linked Ring]] and New York's [[Photo-Secession]].<ref>[http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artMakerDetails?maker=1706 "Sarah Choate Sears"], The J. Paul Getty Museum. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref> [[Elizabeth Buehrmann]] from Chicago (c. 1886–1963) specialized in taking portraits of leading businessmen and prominent society women in their own homes at the beginning of the 20th century, becoming a member of the famous Paris Photo-Club in 1907.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Helen|last=Goodman|date=Winter 1995|title=Elizabeth Buehrmann, American Pictorialist|journal=History of Photography|volume=19|issue=4|pages=338–341|doi=10.1080/03087298.1995.10443589}}</ref> [[Caroline Gurrey]] (1875–1927) is remembered for her series on mixed-race children taken in Hawaii from 1904. Many were exhibited at the [[Alaska–Yukon–Pacific Exposition]] in Seattle.<ref>[http://www.mixedracestudies.org/wordpress/?tag=caroline-haskins-gurrey Heather Waldroup, "Ethnographic Pictorialism: Caroline Gurrey’s Hawaiian Types at the Alaska–Yukon–Pacific Exposition"], Mixed Race Studies. Retrieved 14 May 2013.</ref> [[Doris Ulmann]] (1884–1934) started out as an amateur pictorialist photographer but became a professional in 1918. In addition to portraits of promintent intellectuals, she documented the mountain peoples of the south, especially the [[Appalachia]]ns.<ref>[http://library.uoregon.edu/speccoll/photo/ulmann/index.html "Doris Ulmann Collection"], University of Oregon Libraries. Retrieved 15 May 2013.</ref>
In the 1930s, [[Consuelo Kanaga]] (1894–1978) photographed many well-known artists and writers becoming one of the few photographers to produce artistic portraits. Her photograph of a slender black women and her children was included in [[Edward Steichen]]'s ''[[The Family of Man|Family of Man]]'' exhibition in 1955.<ref>{{cite book|author=Barbara Head Millstein and Susan Lowe|title=Consuelo Kanaga, An American Photographer|publisher=Seattle: University of Washington Press|year=1992|pages=21–40}}</ref> [[Ruth Harriet Louise]] (1903–1940) was first woman photographer active in Hollywood where she ran [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]'s portrait studio from 1925 to 1930 photographing numerous stars including as [[Greta Garbo]] and [[Joan Crawford]].<ref>Dance, R.; B. Robertson, ''Ruth Harriet Louise and Hollywood Glamour Photography'', University of California Press 2002; {{ISBN|0-520-23347-6}}.</ref>
<gallery class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Sears lillies.jpg|[[Sarah Choate Sears]]: Young woman with lilies (c. 1900) File:Portrait of Japanese-Hawaiian and Portugese-Hawaiian boys 1909.jpg|[[Caroline Gurrey]]: ''Portrait of a Japanese-Hawaiian and a Portuguese-Hawaiian Boy'' (1909) File:Henry Adams seated with dog on steps of piazza, photograph by Marian Hooper Adams, ca. 1883.jpg|[[Marian Hooper Adams]]: ''H. Adams & Marquis'' (c. 1883) File:Doris Ulmann - Southern mountaineer.jpg|[[Doris Ulmann]]: ''Southern Mountaineer'' (c. 1928) File:RH Louise Garbo 0.jpg|[[Ruth Harriet Louise]]: Greta Garbo (1927) </gallery>
== African-American women in photography ==
=== History ===
Photographs are pictures ''about'' and ''of'' things (Birt). As society has evolved, African-American photographers have been critical in the preservation of authentic portrayals of images ''about ''and ''of ''black culture. The participation of African-American women in photography began to receive widespread acknowledgment in the mid-20th century and with growing recognition came a shift in focus on social, economic, and political conditions. Some of the most prominent female African-American photographers include [[Carrie Mae Weems]], [[Lorna Simpson]], and [[Coreen Simpson]].
==== Carrie Mae Weems ==== Born in [[Portland, Oregon]], [[Carrie Mae Weems]] started her career in 1973 when she received her first camera. Her initial interest in the arts started in 1965, when she met lifelong friend Tom Vinters and began participating in street theater and dance. Though noted as an accomplished photographer, Weems' work spans text, fabric, audio, digital images, installation, and video. "…from the very beginning I've been interested in the idea of power and the consequences of power; relationships are made and articulated through power."<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Carrie Mae Weems|last = Bey|first = Dawoud|date = Summer 2009|journal = BOMB|doi = |pmid = |jstor=40428266|pages=60–67}}</ref> When exploring the idea of power, Weems oftentimes uses herself as the subject of her work, not for her own admiration, but "as a vehicle for approaching the question of power…"<ref name=":0" />
Through different mediums, Weems has made it her mission to explore the family relationships, gender roles, the histories of racism, sexism, class and different types of political systems.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://carriemaeweems.net/bio.html|title= Carrie Mae Weems|date= |accessdate=12 April 2015 |website = carriemaeweems|publisher = Lisa Goodlin Design|last = Weems|first = Carrie Mae}}</ref> She was introduced to [[Dawoud Bey]] in 1976 and developed a long lasting friendship and professional relationship with the photographer. While on a work trip to Europe, Bey interviewed Weems in BOMB, a magazine focused on artists in conversation. [[File:LornaSimpsonApr09 cropped.jpg|right|150px|thumb|Lorna Simpson]]
==== Lorna Simpson ==== [[Lorna Simpson]] began her career in fashion photography, taking pictures of people whose style she admired. Simpson was able to develop her skills and became a photojournalist who captured images in politics, culture, music, and sports.
Receiving her education in photography at the [[School of Visual Arts]] in New York and the [[University of California, San Diego]], Lorna Simpson was considered a pioneer of conceptual photography well before the peak of her career. Through her work, Simpson aims to challenge the traditional views of gender, identity, culture, history, and memory as viewed by society. Her combination of large-scale photography with meaningful text work together to provide strong visual implications.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.lsimpsonstudio.com/#mi=11&pt=0&pi=6&p=-1&a=-1&at=0|title = Lorna Simpson|accessdate =15 April 2015|website = Lorna Simpson Studio|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
Her work can be found in museums across the country at the [[Museum of Modern Art, New York|Museum of Modern Art]] (NY), the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago|Museum of Contemporary Art]] (Chicago, IL), and the [[Walker Art Center]] (Minneapolis), and many others around the world.
==== Coreen Simpson ==== Making her mark as a photojournalist, [[Coreen Simpson]] started her career as a published writer. Her interest in documenting experiences in writing grew into a love for the visual arts when she contacted Essence magazine about an article she wanted to write about a business trip to the Middle East. Although the article was never published, her interest in photojournalism was heightened.
In his article "Coreen Simpson: An Interpretation", Rodger Birt describes looking at a photograph as being "let in on the workings of another human consciousness" allowing for the simultaneous opportunity to receive an authentic depiction of the physical world.<ref name="Birt">{{cite journal|last1=Birt|first1=Rodger|title=Coreen Simpson: An Interpretation|journal=Black American Literature Forum|date=1987|volume=21|issue=3|pages=289–304|jstor=2904032|doi=10.2307/2904032}}</ref> Through her work, Simpson has created visual narratives that aesthetically tell the stories of diverse groups of people. Not only is she able to evoke emotional responses through her storytelling, but through design, [[chiaroscuro]], and color as well.
Simpson's friend, Walter Johnson, became one of her biggest mentors and guide as she expanded her knowledge in photography. She also studied Frank Stewart's process and developed a strong capacity for the history of photography. One of her biggest struggles was to differentiate her visual style from those of her inspiration.
The four greatest influences of Simpson's work include [[Diane Arbus]], [[Adolph de Meyer|Baron Adolph DeMeyer]], [[Joel Peter Witkin]], and [[Weegee]]. Whether conceptually, methodically, or creatively, each of these photographers have contributed to her approach in different ways.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|jstor = 2904032|title = Coreen Simpson: An Interpretation|last = Birt|first = Rodger|date = Autumn 1997|journal = Black American Literature Forum|doi = |pmid = }}</ref>
The combination of her admiration for Arbus's uniqueness, Weegee's hunt, DeMeyer's study of the compostition, and Witkin's manipulation of the print work together in encompassing the personality of Coreen Simpson's work.<ref name=":1" />
'''Elizabeth "Tex" Williams'''
[[Elizabeth Williams (photographer)|Elizabeth "Tex" Williams]] was a world war 2 military photographer. She was in the last year of war.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/29733207|title=Viewfinders : black women photographers|last=1951-|first=Moutoussamy-Ashe, Jeanne,|date=1993|publisher=Writers & Readers Pub|isbn=0863161588|location=New York|oclc=29733207}}</ref> She was one of the first women to have a photography career beyond "camera girl".<ref name="auto"/>
==UK women's agency== In the [[United Kingdom]] the women's photographic agency [[Format (photographic agency)|Format]] was set up in 1983, from an idea conceived by Maggie Murray and [[Val Wilmer]].<ref>[http://sounds.bl.uk/Arts-literature-and-performance/Art-photography-and-architecture/021M-C0459X0046XX-1200V0 "Art, photography & architecture: Wilmer, Val (12 of 13). Oral History of British Photography"], [[British Library]], Sounds.</ref><ref>Amanda Hopkinson, [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/sep/21/raissa-page-obituary "Raissa Page obituary"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 September 2011.</ref> Operating for two decades, until 2003, Format represented women photographers including Jackie Chapman, [[Anita Corbin]], [[Melanie Friend]], Sheila Gray, Paula Glassman, Judy Harrison, Pam Isherwood, [[Roshini Kempadoo]], Jenny Mathews, Joanne O'Brien, Raissa Page, Brenda Prince, Ulrike Preuss, Mirium Reik, Karen Robinson, Paula Solloway, Mo Wilson and Lisa Woollett.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cpt.qedstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/format-photographers.pdf|title="Format Photographers Agency 1983–2003".|author=|date=|website=qedstudio.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.photofusion.org/exhibitions/ultimate-format/ "Ultimate Format | Format Women Photographers 1983 – 2003"], Photofusion.</ref>
==Contemporary== Contemporary women photographers continue to break ground in the field of photography. [[Annie Leibovitz]] captures arresting, usually posed, images of the famous and the unknown, publishing photographs for the covers of ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', ''Vogue'', and ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', representing a broad survey of American popular culture.<ref>[http://www.infoplease.com/encyclopedia/people/leibovitz-annie.html "Annie Leibovitz"], Infoplease. Retrieved 14 December 2015.</ref>
[[Cindy Sherman]]'s work turns still photography into performance art to explore traditional and pop-cultural myths of femininity. Her work implicitly examines issues of identity and stereotype, representation and reality, the function of mass media, and the nature of portraiture.<ref>[http://www.infoplease.com/encyclopedia/people/sherman-cindy.html "Cindy Sherman"], Infoplease. Retrieved 14 December 2015.</ref>
The contemporary works of women photographers is numerous. Women only photography exhibits are controversial yet essential to highlight the imbalance of male domination in the field throughout the history of photography, and are becoming increasingly more common.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2018-05-11|title=Female Artists Are (Finally) Getting Their Turn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/03/arts/design/the-resurgence-of-women-only-art-shows.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=29 March 2016|issn=0362-4331|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2018-05-11|title=‘Women in Photography’ explores diverse possibilities of familiar medium|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/visual-arts/women-in-photography-explores-diverse-possibilities-of-familiar-medium/|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=29 August 2017}}</ref>
==Awards== In 1903, [[Emma Barton (photographer)|Emma Barton]] (1872–1938) was the first woman to be awarded the [[Royal Photographic Society]] medal. It was for a [[carbon print]] entitled ''The Awakening''.<ref>[http://www.nationalmediamuseum.org.uk/Collection/Photography/RoyalPhotographicSociety/CollectionItem.aspx?id=2003-5001/2/20914 "The Awakening"], Royal Photographic Society. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref>
The [[Pulitzer Prize for Photography]] has been awarded to outstanding work in press photography since 1942. The first woman to receive the award was [[Virginia Schau]] (1915–1989), an amateur who photographed two men being rescued from a tractor trailer cab as it dangled from a bridge in [[Redding, California]].<ref>Frank Van Riper, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/photo/galleries/essays/001229.htm "Pulitzer Pictures: Capturing the Moment"], Washingtonpost.com. Retrieved 26 May 2013.</ref>
In 2000, Marcia Reed (born 1948), the first female still photographer to join the [[International Cinematographers Guild]] also became the first women to win the [[Society of Operating Cameramen]] Lifetime Achievement Award for Still Photography in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://socawards.com/past-soc-lifetime-achievement-awards/|title=PAST SOC LIFETIME ACHIEVEMENT AWARDS|author=|date=6 December 2014|website=socawards.com}}</ref>
